webTitle: Spook spoof scares off the competition at US box office

fields.headline: Spook spoof scares off the competition at US box office
fields.trailText: A week after two big-money, high-profile blockbusters, The Perfect Storm and The Patriot, crashed into the top two box-office slots in the States, a low-budget horror spoof - Scary Movie - has overtaken them both and gone straight in at number one
fields.body:
A week after two big-money, high-profile blockbusters, The Perfect Storm and The Patriot, crashed into the top two box-office slots in the States, a low-budget horror spoof - Scary Movie - has overtaken them both and gone straight in at number one.

Scary Movie grossed $42.5m in its first three days of release, making it the second biggest opener of the year after Mission: Impossible 2, which grossed $57.9m. It is quite an achievement for a low-budget film which only cost around $19m to make. The Perfect Storm (now at number two) and The Patriot (number three) cost over $140m each, and Mel Gibson, alone, took a $25m pay cheque for his role in The Patriot.

Scary Movie, directed by Keenen Ivory Wayans, stars his two younger brothers Shawn and Marlon and combines elements of the horror films Scream and I Know What You Did Last Summer while also paying homage to such works as Shakespeare in Love and The Usual Suspects.

Film critics in the States applauded the film, which features gratuitous male nudity, raunchy dialogue and drug use. The plaudits were not echoed by the director's parents, however, who walked out of a preview in disgust (see our report). The producers insist that the film is a comedy: "If people want to laugh, this is the movie they're going to," said Miramax spokesman Dennis Rice.

fields.headline: Know your (new) rights
fields.standfirst:
Some part-time workers can now claim more pay and better holidays. But, don't expect your boss to tell you about it, says Kate Hilpern - find out for yourself
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Chances are that your reaction to the new regulations governing part-time workers is one of (a) complete bewilderment, or (b) sheer boredom. Talk of European Directives and Compliance Guidance has been dry, complicated and theoretical.
fields.body:
Chances are that your reaction to the new regulations governing part-time workers is one of (a) complete bewilderment, or (b) sheer boredom. Talk of European Directives and Compliance Guidance has been dry, complicated and theoretical. But, says the Institute for Employment Studies (IES), now that the regulations are in force, it's essential for support staff - who account for a large proportion of part-timers - to get to grips with their new rights or risk losing out in their pay-packets, promotion prospects and even the number of days they spend lazing on sun-loungers this summer.

"Of particular concern is that a huge number of secretaries don't realise that it's up to them to make sure their employers are treating them according to the new laws. They assume their employers will continually update their contracts to become legal whereas this very often doesn't happen," explains Dr Jo Rick, principal research fellow at the IES.

It works like this. Europe as a whole realised that part-time workers were being discriminated against, big-time. Rarely were they given the same opportunities to climb the career ladder as their full-time colleagues and, in addition, they were often paid a lower hourly rate and were ineligible for proper holiday entitlement and maternity/parental leave. Part-timers also tended to be excluded from training.

The result? The development of a European Directive which provided guidelines for the British government to come up with its own, more specific regulations. Not only do these regulations - which came into force on July 1 - state that all those methods of discrimination are now illegal, but they apply to employees and workers, including agency workers and homeworkers.

"So if you work for a recruitment agency and discover that you're not getting the same proportionate level of annual leave as a full-time worker with the same agency, you no longer have to put up with it," says Sarah Eldoori, spokesperson for recruitment agency Office Angels.

"Mind you, there will still be one difference between employees and workers," points out Diane Sinclair, policy adviser to the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development. "The right not to be unfairly dismissed will still be available only to employees."

For those part-time employees, though, the new regulations simplify the legal position. "Before the regulations came in, any part-timer - 80% of whom are women - wanting to take legal action against an employer for detrimental treatment had to claim indirect sex discrimination. In other words, the part-timer had to identify a man in a full-time position within the same company to compare themselves to. Now, being treated less favourably because you are a part-timer will be sufficient grounds in itself," says Sinclair.

But, she adds, here lies another catch: "If you want to pursue a claim because you're getting a lower rate of overtime or less access to a pension scheme on a pro-rata basis than a comparable full-timer, you've still got to identify someone to prove it. OK, they don't have to be male, but they do have to have a similar contract, work for the same employer and have a similar level of skills and experience. In small companies, that isn't exactly easy," she points out.

So what's the first step for the average part-time secretary to ensure that an employer is taking account of the new rules? If you suspect you are being treated less favourably than full-time colleagues, you should make a written request to your employer for an explanation. The employer is legally bound to respond in writing within 21 days.

There may be occasions when the boss will admit that the full-time secretary is indeed getting private healthcare cover while you, as a part-timer, remain stuck on NHS waiting lists. "But before you storm out of the office to visit the nearest lawyer, you should be aware that when it comes to benefits - whether we are talking profit-sharing, subsidised mortgages or staff discounts - employers do have the right to exclude part-time workers so long as there are objective grounds," says a TUC spokesperson.

Imagine, for instance, that you work 18 hours a week and you complain that Michelle down the corridor, who does the same job as you for 36 hours a week, has been given a company car. Your employer would be justified in claiming that he can't cut a vehicle in half, and even if he were to provide you with an L-reg Mini Metro, it would be of disproportionate cost to the organisation.

According to Julie Edwards, employment partner at Edge solicitors in Birmingham, this is the most contentious area of the regulations, and will undoubtedly cause such confusion to some secretaries that they won't bother making a claim even when entitled to. In fact, she adds, this isn't the only flaw. While the regulations aim to encourage an increase in part-time working, there is still no right for a worker to demand to work on a part-time basis, even when it is a reasonable request.

"The directive's more aspirational elements are addressed in the 'best practice guidance' which accompanies the regulations," she says. "Employers are merely encouraged to make a wider range of jobs available part-time, to make part-time work more accessible, including introducing flexible terms of working. But the guidance notes have no teeth and employers can simply choose to ignore them."

fields.headline: Following in your leader's footsteps
fields.standfirst:
Where does a secretary's loyalty lie - with the company, or the boss? Helene Mulholland considers the poaching of staff, a practice that is becoming increasingly common
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Last week, the traditional image of the loyal secretary was shaken by the news that the secretary of a Labour politician had been poached by the Tories to work for shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude.
fields.body:
Last week, the traditional image of the loyal secretary was shaken by the news that the secretary of a Labour politician had been poached by the Tories to work for shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude. Worse still, this is the second time that secretary Anna Tolchard has crossed the political floor in less than a year. When her then boss, MP Shaun Woodward, defected from the Conservative party to Labour at the end of last year, she followed him. But loyalty to her boss has been superseded by loyalty to the Tories - or so the party's spin machine would have you believe. The Tories are thrilled at her return to the fold (one has labelled her a "super secretary"), although she and Woodward are said to have parted on good terms.

We hear much about the poaching of senior management professionals. Indeed, whole businesses are set up on the back of head-hunting or "searches" for the right person by shrewd companies, particularly in niche markets where there is a small pool of experts to choose from. But stealing secretaries seems anathema to a profession known for its discretion and loyalty. Does it really happen within the administrative tier?

A recent survey of support staff showed that the majority of companies still use agencies to find their employees, with media advertising and informal networks also quite common. When Louise Marks's boss left the branch of a holding company for head office, his recommendation of her to colleagues there allowed her a move of her own to HQ, though not to work for him. "It was an excuse to get away from where I was, though the particular job he got me was working for a guy who was so boring that I got another job in-house within six weeks," she says.

Word of mouth is one thing. But the consensus on formal head-hunting techniques within the administrative sphere is that these methods are rare. Richard Grace is managing director of recruitment agency Gordon Yates. He has yet to hear of an agency that provides a major service in the head-hunting of office staff. "It doesn't lend itself to support staff," he explains. "The population is much too large and not quite so defined."

One reason is that the fit between boss and secretary seems to be more important than one might expect in a usual working relationship. "Secretarial work is a unique assignment, in that personality is such an important part of the match, especially at more executive levels," says Grace. "People form a pairing, and will consider that aspect if the boss moves across."

Another scenario is when a boss returns to a trusted past employee when they can't find someone suitable to fill a post. Marjorie Mair, a consultant at the Industrial Society, believes that bosses often come back to what they know: "Some people say poaching doesn't happen anymore, and others say there is more chance of it. There is a skills shortage and if somebody knows a really good PA and is having trouble recruiting, the first thing they will do is pick up the phone and ask if they need a job. You have to know the person as well as the work to do the job well."

The effective relationship requires professional respect and an understanding of the person, as a professional and an individual. When a PA makes decisions for the boss, however small, they anticipate what that person will need and how he or she wants it done. This customised role is optimised when strong, mutual bonds are secured between the two colleagues. That close relationship will in turn engender a loyalty that will stand the boss in good stead.

Patricia Constant faced a similar dilemma to that of Anna Tolchard, when her own boss, Conservative MP Alan Howarth, crossed to the Labour benches before the last general election. Mutual loyalty and respect won out. "When Alan crossed the floor, I thought he was jeopardising his political career," she says. "I didn't expect him to get a seat, since in the Labour party there is no question of fixing seats in the Commons. I expected him to lose his job - and me to lose mine - whenever the next election came, so it was not the best career move. But I thought he was very brave, and knew he was going to be pilloried and get a lot of personal attention, and I wasn't going to leave him in the lurch." As it turned out, Howarth was elected as Labour MP for Newport in Wales, and is currently junior minister for the Arts. Constant continues to work for him.

Constant's experience illustrates the most common style of poaching in the secretarial field: when the boss is head-hunted, promoted or just chooses to leave for better pastures, the secretary might be asked to go too. Patricia Constant understands the reasons for that all too well: "When two people work closely, particularly in the type of work where it is very much one-to-one and you work long hours, it is not surprising that personality plays a large part."

But the assertive secretary has more to gain than just keeping a good working relationship. If the boss is poached for better prospects, it means the secretary's own status will improve. Cheryl Carter was PA to Rebekah Wade, deputy editor of the Sun. When the latter was recently appointed editor of the News of the World, Carter followed, a move that automatically enhanced her own career prospects.

Something to consider when thinking of following one's colleague is why they are asking you to join them. Is it because they value you and the relationship, or, in the case of the more difficult characters, because they know you will put up with their unreasonable behaviour? Basil Fawlty would have been lucky to have found two Pollys in one lifetime to deal with his antics. And, loyalty aside, is the career move as good for you as for your boss?

Companies wanting to retain valued staff in the face of poaching of whatever kind might like to think about the terms, conditions and pay they are offering, to counter the seduction of the greener grass on the other side. After all, we'd all like to think that Francis Maude's new secretary was recruited with the offer of a pay rise and a more developed professional role.

fields.headline: BT confirms Concert sale plan
fields.standfirst: Move comes amid calls for change and reports of a divided boardroom
fields.trailText: British Telecom yesterday confirmed that it was considering a flotation of Concert, its business telecoms joint venture, following intense pressure for change from disgruntled shareholders.
fields.body:
British Telecom yesterday confirmed that it was considering a flotation of Concert, its business telecoms joint venture, following intense pressure for change from disgruntled shareholders.

The company leapt to the defence of its chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, following reports that he is a boardroom "blocker" opposed to reforms.

BT has been struggling to reverse a steady decline in its share price. Many institutions want the group to separate its faster growing internet and new media businesses from its traditional fixed-line telephone network. Concert, which is valued at up to £15bn, is considered one of the group's most promising ventures. It is jointly owned by BT and the US group AT&T.

A BT spokesman yesterday said that the prospects for a flotation were being reviewed by the two partners and by Concert's management: "We're not ruling anything in or out. It's something that's being discussed between the three of us."

A public offering of just a small slice of Concert - possibly 20% - would raise substantial cash to fund expansion. The spokesman said: "Our key priority is to grow the business and make it a world beater."

Such a move would also enable Concert to offer share options to its senior management, which could help attract and retain talented people.

Concert is expected to notch up sales of about $7bn (£4.6bn) this year. The business pools the cross-border networks of its two parent companies to create an international phone and internet service for multinational corporations.

BT's chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield has already announced plans to float Yell, the group's yellow pages division, for about £5bn. However, there has been frustration at the slow pace of change at the company.

BT yesterday rejected reports that the board was divided, with an "old guard" led by Sir Iain putting the brakes on. The spokesman said: "The board is giving the restructuring its full support and is fully behind the chairman."

He poured cold water on suggestions that Sir Iain could retire before his contract expires in 2002: "He is committed to his current contract and the company is committed to him."

Sir Iain is taking on an extra responsibility in July - he becomes president of the Confederation of British Industry.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: TOP DOG
fields.body:
TOP DOG

Do you have a great working relationship with your boss? Does your boss trust you to manage his or her time? Do you share the same sense of humour? Here's your chance to tell the world. Lion Television is making a documentary about the workplace and is keen to film a PA and boss who make a great team. Call Anoushka (in strict confidence) on 020 8735 4073, or email anoushkac@liontv.co.uk

 GET AHEAD

It's so obvious, it's hard to believe nobody's thought of it before... Hi-tech company edesigns has developed a package that allows you to put your company letterhead and logo on all your emails, giving your messages the impact of your other corporate communications. The "eletterhead" is easily installed and "brands" each email automatically. Prices start at £35.99. Call 020 7813 3449, or visit www.edesigns.co.uk

 HOLIDAY UNCOVERED

Before you rush off to laze on a foreign beach, do you spare a thought for your replacement? Leading temp placement agency Blue Arrow says requests for temps soar by up to 40% over the holiday season. But not enough workers leave clear instructions, making it hard for stand-in staff to do an effective job. Blue Arrow recommends giving temps a task list and clear handover notes. Introduce temps to other staff, give them computer passwords, and ensure they know the company style for letters. Last, but not least, let them know about working hours, lunchtimes and breaks.

 BOSS THE BOSS

Assertiveness is growing among today's secretaries, according to research into the relationship between PAs and bosses. Eight out of 10 secretaries reported that they had said "no" to a request from their managers. But there's no desire to be difficult: 6 out of 10 of the secretaries polled admired their bosses "very much". More than half admitted to lying "sometimes or regularly" to cover up for those above them. But the thing that most wound up PAs was making last-minute changes to managers' travel plans: 70% reckoned it wasn't unusual for arrangements to alter as many as 20 times.

 NET RESULT

Are you being asked to work on your company's website? Do you regularly update its intranet? If so, a course from training provider Hemsley Fraser could be useful. The Professional Web Developer covers web development and design, intranets and e-commerce. No previous experience is required and the course will appeal to PAs and executive secretaries involved in their firm's internet presence. Call Hemsley Fraser on 01752 849400 for more details.

Eight out of 10 secretaries reported that they had said "no" to a request from their managers. But there's no desire to be difficult: 6 out of 10 of the secretaries polled admired their bosses "very much". But the thing that most wound up PAs was making last-minute changes to managers' travel plans: 70% reckoned it wasn't unusual for arrangements to alter as many as 20 times.  NET RESULT Are you being asked to work on your company's website? Do you regularly update its intranet? If so, a course from training provider Hemsley Fraser could be useful. The Professional Web Developer covers web development and design, intranets and e-commerce. No previous experience is required and the course will appeal to PAs and executive secretaries involved in their firm's internet presence. Call Hemsley Fraser on 01752 849400 for more details.

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 27: The letter clip
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Otherwise known as the bulldog clip, and not to be confused with the nipple clamp, the letter clip is undeniably the king of temporary collation. With a name that strikes fear into the heart of the meanest stray invoice, there is no doubt that its mission is to create order in the most chaotic of offices, with almost military efficiency.
fields.body:
Otherwise known as the bulldog clip, and not to be confused with the nipple clamp, the letter clip is undeniably the king of temporary collation. With a name that strikes fear into the heart of the meanest stray invoice, there is no doubt that its mission is to create order in the most chaotic of offices, with almost military efficiency. Indeed, if the stationery cupboard were an arsenal, then the bulldog clip would be part of the heavy artillery. With no frills, no spangly colours to choose from, no airy-fairy attachments, this clip means business.

A thoroughly British clip, the bulldog was first produced in 1892, all clips bearing a stamp of the year in which they were forged. As patriotic as any other British bulldog, the original manufacturers, Setten and Durword, claim that "it's performing admirably against the challenge of lower quality imports from the far east".

With fully paid-up membership to the Dangerous Clips Club, the bulldog should come with a health warning. In keeping with its bad-boy image is a string of offences as long as . . . well, a string, with this week's icon responsible for innumerable injuries involving fingertips, ear lobes and other extremities.

Boasting a grip not unlike that of its fierce canine namesake, this clip should be approached with caution. It is stronger than it looks.

No doubt children, and some of the more overworked and demented among us, persist in employing the bulldog in the pursuit of evil, torture being a favourite rebel use for the clip. Ignoring the fact that it works like a dream and is an indispensable addition to any top drawer, they prefer to use it in combat with the boss in its capacity as a digit menace. Just leave one on the desk, let curiosity take over, sit back and enjoy...

fields.headline: Music review: Pop
fields.trailText: My Vitriol *** Roadhouse, Manchester
fields.body:
Pop My Vitriol *** Roadhouse, Manchester

My Vitriol opened their 40-minute set with their last single, Always Your Way, their punkish youthfulness and thrashy guitars redolent of early Ash with a touch of Rage thrown in. But My Vitriol are not as caustic as their name suggests. They break up their well-structured compositions by dropping in drifting strings, with plenty of distortion and delay, and simple but nifty bass-lines. This is staying-in and going-out music at the same time.

Even when the guitars started wailing again, and the drummer sounded as if he was battering a biscuit tin, the strong melodies prevented the songs from tumbling into a grungy obscurity. This was partly due to the clear vocals of frontman Som Wardner, which lie nicely over the fast, brash guitars and offer catchy refrains and harmonies worthy of Teenage Fan Club before they ran out of songs.

Indeed, My Vitriol's new single Cemented Shoes takes the best of the Fannies, roughs them up and spirals towards a crazed finale. Dreamy guitar hooks and clever vocal nuances usher the song into ballad territory, only for it to speed up with all the mad defiance of a car going the wrong way up the motorway.

Favouring long intros, the four-piece slowly develop bass and drums beneath a sharp riff, and it's the combination of this navel-gazing and hysterical abandonment that has led some to compare them to US underground bands. The music is all edges, and the despair is there if you want to tap into it, but there's a jauntiness to My Vitriol that means they stomp up a formidable kind of pop-rock.

fields.headline: Come together
fields.trailText: Oasis Landsdowne Road, Dublin ****
fields.body:
Oasis Landsdowne Road, Dublin ****

Ever since the days of their Britpop infamy, Oasis have resembled something between a macabre drama and a deranged soap opera. The recent episodes alone would keep Coronation Street scriptwriters in jobs for several years: rhythm section quits in acrimony; rejigged band release "classic" comeback album; songwriter (Noel Gallagher) admits "classic" comeback album is crap; a feud over "lifestyle" prompts a newly drug-free Noel to walk out in disgust; wildman brother, Liam, and a cobbled together Oasis tour Europe without him. Impeccably and inevitably (and following tabloid stories of touring benders), the day before his crucial homecoming(ish) gig, Liam's wife (Patsy Kensit) walks out.

So it's hard to know which is the greater surprise: that Noel is back, or that brother Liam is still with us. There is an argument which says that minus three of their original lineup, Oasis will never be the force that spawned Definitely Maybe. Few bands could withstand such losses, but Oasis are one of them. This is partly because of the simple construction of their music but mainly because of the fearsome charisma of the Gallaghers.

For the first few numbers this is all that sustains them. Liam, surprisingly, cuts a more mature figure than the boorish lout we have loved/hated, and Noel's stony face holds an entire storybook. Hampered by high winds and poor sound, Who Feels Love, one of the only three cuts from Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants, all but blows into the sea. However, as a sliver of a grin creeps across the senior Gallagher's face, Oasis deliver.

The key is Acquiesce. This song of brotherly togetherness has never sounded more inappropriate, nor more poignant. As the younger Gallagher finishes hurling out the lyrics, he announces: "Don't believe what you read in the papers. We're not splitting up." The crowd roar and Liam walks across the stage to shake his brother's hand. From anyone else, this would have seemed absurdly scripted, but this sincere moment proves the turning point in the gig.

Playing Shakermaker, Stand By Me, Wonderwall, Oasis seem to be rediscovering what had made them good. Although there's something curiously dated about the (mainly male) audience's sea of casual tops, these ageing sing-along songs take the wider canvas and the band fill in the details. Cigarettes & Alcohol is rather mischievously dedicated by Liam "to Blair's son, I think it's brilliant". Inevitably, Noel chips in. "This one's called Rock'n'Roll Star, and we are," he says, attitude undiminished by his regretted two years in the Met bar.

Occasionally, the band reach the heady heights of their classic 1990s Maine Road shows. Noel seems genuinely moved when the crowd sing Don't Look Back In Anger. Most strikingly, a young fan dances precariously on the roof of the mixing desk tent during Live Forever, risking everything for a glimpse of immortality as the band's anthem is accompanied by gasps from the crowd.

Heavyweight stuff, but questions remain over Oasis's own lifespan. Can they rediscover this spark on record? More to the point, will the senior Gallagher remain? Noel's solo performance of Neil Young's Hey Hey, My My (Into The Black) with the lyric "It's better to burn out than fade away" seems unusually provocative. But this would be a curious time to bow out. Far from the expected Tysonesque freakshow, Oasis sound like a great band limbering up for another shot at the title.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It might sound a bit clichéd, but knowing that you spend your days doing something worthwhile does make a big difference," says Jo Simmons, PA to the director of the fund-raising division at Shelter, which campaigns for the homeless.
fields.body:
It might sound a bit clichéd, but knowing that you spend your days doing something worthwhile does make a big difference," says Jo Simmons, PA to the director of the fund-raising division at Shelter, which campaigns for the homeless.

"It's a good combination: I'm in the fundraising department, so I still get the excitement of being in business - because of the need to raise money - but at the same time I know I am working for a good cause."

Simmons combines general support duties for the fund- raising division with PA duties to the director of the department. "What's nice is that my work is very varied. I do a lot of conventional secretarial work for my boss, Alan Gosschalk, such as audio-typing, arranging meetings and sorting out presentations, but then I do all sorts of other things as well. There are often different projects to raise money and I tend to get involved with administering them."

With just three months under her belt at Shelter, Simmons already believes that working for a charity is very different from toiling away in the corporate sector. "What's so nice is that it's really not hierarchical. Everyone is on first-name terms, from the director downwards, and everyone has a voice in the company."

Part of her role as PA is to take minutes at some of the many meetings her boss attends, but she doesn't simply sit silently at the back. "Everyone is welcome to chip in - if you have an idea or an opinion, then you will be listened to," she says. "It makes me feel that I'm really involved with the company and that I have an important role to play."

Unlike many corporate businesses, working for a charity often involves getting out and about to see its work in action, as Simmons has already found. "I recently visited the Piccadilly advice centre and the ShelterLine offices, and soon I'm going up to Sheffield to see the housing aid centre. It all adds up to gaining a more in-depth knowledge of the charity, so that in the future I can go along to meetings and fundraising events and talk about what the money donated is spent on."

Simmons believes that the key to working for a charity is to be flexible. "You can't be too structured. Because it's quite a creative place, you have to be able to go with the flow and juggle your work. Sometimes everyone has to drop whatever they're doing and help someone out - for example, if there is a mailshot it might mean that 1,000 envelopes need to be stuffed by the end of the day. But what's nice is that it's not just support staff who end up doing the boring jobs - everyone lends a hand."

And working for a charity means that work doesn't stop at 5.30 in the evening. "It really makes you aware of the issues, and with Shelter I'm increasingly aware of the problems of homelessness. I find myself constantly listening out for any items on the radio or TV that deal with the issue - and being that interested in my job feels great."

fields.headline: Halifax goes for net point
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Halifax is putting clicks into its bricks by installing internet access in its branch network.
fields.body:
Halifax is putting clicks into its bricks by installing internet access in its branch network.

The 600 "click-and-call" internet points, which will cost Halifax "a couple of million pounds" to install, will only allow customers access to the bank's sites rather than the whole of cyberspace.

However, by putting access to the internet into its branches the bank will be able to make accounts that are solely available on the web - such as websave - available to people without internet access. The move could prove crucial at a time when the government is trying to end discrimination against poorer sections of the community. Internet-only products often pay better savings rates and charge lower borrowing rates than branch or telephone accounts.

The government is also trying to win support for its "IT For All" campaign.

"This is all about bringing the internet to the high street in a way that is convenient for all of our customers," said David Walkden, general manager of Halifax Direct, the bank's telephone and internet arm.

Through these so-called "click-and-call" points customers can access all Halifax's websites as well as Rightmove, an estate agency website backed by the Halifax.

Rightmove

fields.headline: Theatre review
fields.trailText: York Millennium Mystery Plays **** York Minster
fields.body:
York Millennium Mystery Plays **** York Minster

The original pageant-procession of Biblical playlets saw the Creation cart set out at 4.30am and the Doomsday wagon finally wending its way home some time after midnight. Recent revivals of the Mysteries in York have tended to feel somewhat longer. Committed audiences have sat shivering amidst the ruins of St Mary's Abbey, grimly aware that the entire Old Testament must grind by before the first toilet break.

Charged with the task of producing something special for the millennium, director Gregory Doran has brought the plays indoors to the magisterial nave of the Minster, and crafted what may be the best-sustained modern account of the plays so far.

It's long, of course. God may have created the world in seven days; but even He would struggle to pack this rumbustious compendium of His works into less than four hours. Doran proves adept at herding huge numbers of people fluently and meaningfully, but where this production really scores is its attention to coaching the principals' performances. Only Ray Stevenson, playing Jesus, is a professional.

Recent approaches to the Mysteries have been mysterious indeed - God as a schoolboy, God as a woman, the world as a building site, Robson Green as the Son of God. But from the moment John M Hall's all-seeing Creator appears, it becomes apparent that Doran has played with a straight bat, and reverted to the image of God as a stentorian grey-beard in a white sheet. Not that the show is without colour: Doran and designer Robert Jones pinpoint the main figures with the blazing lucidity of stained glass, while Richard Shephard's brassy score stirs up the Minster's sluggish acoustics. Mike Poulton's gutsy new performing version puts paid to fears that these robust dramas would have to be toned down if brought back into church. Rarely can the word "bollocks" have rung around the nave so lustily.

Till July 22. Box office: 01904 673535.

fields.headline: Music review: Opera
fields.trailText: Earth and the Great Weather *** Almeida, London
fields.body:
Opera Earth and the Great Weather *** Almeida, London

How does the idea of Alaskan minimalism grab you? I have to confess that by the end of the UK premiere of John Luther Adams's Earth and the Great Weather, I wasn't exactly a convert, but the audience reception was enthusiastic, so I might be in the minority. "Minimalist" is perhaps slightly too narrow a term to describe the work, since Adams's music shows a wide range of influences, as well as a desire to forge a unique language of its own.

Not to be confused with John Adams of Nixon in China fame, this Adams trained in California before opting out of the west coast avant-garde and making Alaska his home in 1974. Frank Zappa was one of his early idols. The pared-down sonorities and harmonic tenacity of Morton Feldman hover in the background, as does John Cage's equation of experimentation with spirituality.

Though billed as part of the Almeida Opera season, Earth and the Great Weather is essentially a big multimedia piece. Adams calls it a "sonic geography of the Arctic", evoking the permanence and change of a primal northern landscape, its indigenous peoples and their spirituality. "They," a programme note states, referring to the area's Inuit and native American population, "define space more by sound than by sight."

The Almeida gradually fills with taped sound as elusive images are projected on to the blank screen that forms the backdrop of the set. Voices whisper in both English and Inuit as trees rustle in the wind. Sustained string chords suggest vastness. On stage, the vocal group Synergy sustain melismatic phrases that interweave canonically with a delayed relay of their own voices. To begin with, the result is hypnotic, at times almost soporific, a portrait of a seemingly benevolent nature and of man in tune with it.

Yet its calm is illusory - this world can turn harsh and violent in an instant. The floor of the stage is strewn with boulders, through which flames suddenly shoot, and across which Synergy stumble and totter. Thunder ricochets from the speakers. The projection screens turn fiery red and become translucent to reveal a percussion group in the Almeida gallery, who fill the air with clattering cross rhythms based on native American music, though suggestive of some overpowering cataclysm.

Peter Mumford's production is unfailingly impressive, as are the performances, but the score sometimes buckles under the weight of what it tries to portray. Adams's musical language, though sometimes beautiful, isn't always rich enough to sustain a work that runs for nearly an hour and a half. Many enjoyed it; I was left cold.

fields.headline: Workouts without leaving your desk
fields.standfirst:
Never have time to make it to the gym in your lunch hour? Don't despair - you can get fit while gazing at your computer
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The kit consists of a mouthpiece connected to a PC or laptop. A software programme guides the user through a set of breathing exercises, and microelectronics link the mouthpiece with the computer programme to provide biofeedback.
fields.body:
As we struggle to squeeze more activities into increasingly hectic lives, many people are trying to make the most of their time by fitting exercise into their working day. Of course, women's magazines have been extolling the virtues of keeping in shape while at work for many years. However, while it's quite acceptable to flex your calf muscles discreetly or make dainty circular movements with your toes, alternately clenching each buttock in order to achieve a firm derrière while tapping away at your PC might result in less enlightened colleagues avoiding your immediate vicinity for a couple of hours, under the misapprehension that you are suffering from chronic wind.

A recent book, Workouts for Workaholics (Crunch Fitness Guides, £8.20), which suggests routines you can sweat to during office hours, takes things a bit further and suggests you use everyday objects to help in your quest. If you do decide to use your briefcase as a dumb-bell, however, it's best not to look too serious, as your rapt concentration could be mistaken for aggression and you might find yourself escorted from the building. On the other hand, smiling too broadly will look equally deranged.

Rosalyn Palmer, of Rosalyn Palmer PR, took a pro-active approach to fitness at work and installed a step machine and a small trampoline in her office for staff to use. "I thought people might find it useful when they were feeling stressed, but although everyone thought it was a good idea in principle, it never really took off. I think people felt a bit self-conscious exercising in front of colleagues, and it wasn't always practical. You can't go bouncing around on a trampoline when you're dressed up for a meeting with a client."

When Palmer moved offices, she decided not to bring the equipment with her, but found a very successful alternative: "We have a masseuse who regularly visits, and a stress-busting chair discreetly tucked away in a corner so people can have a massage without having to undress. I can think of occasions when just the appearance of the masseuse has raised a cheer, so it must be doing some good."

Desk-bound workaholics who are anxious that using the stairs rather than the lift doesn't quite compensate for the hours spent with one's backside glued to a swivel chair, might be interested in an electronic "breathing kit" which strengthens the body's respiratory muscles and improves overall fitness - and all while you are sitting at your desk. Developed in conjunction with physiotherapists, Trainair, launched last week at the Tomorrow's World Live event at Earls Court, claims to help people of all ages increase their capacity for exercise.

The kit consists of a mouthpiece connected to a PC or laptop. A software programme guides the user through a set of breathing exercises, and microelectronics link the mouthpiece with the computer programme to provide biofeedback. Nevertheless, you'll need an understanding boss - the 30-minute workout needs to be repeated three times a week.

Most employers are conscious that fit and healthy staff tend to suffer less stress and work more productively - hence the growing trend for large organisations to have in-house fitness facilities or to offer subsidised membership to a gym.

Perhaps we should be asking, though, why it is necessary to integrate exercise into the working day. Although many people might welcome the chance to pack more into the nine-to-five, leaving them free to pursue more pleasurable pursuits in their own time, the reality is that we spend too much time at work. The office can, of course, be a very sociable place: colleagues can become good friends, and an increasing number of people meet their partners at work. Now, it seems, you can find an exercise buddy there, too.

fields.headline: Walsh swansong in doubt
fields.trailText: Courtney Walsh could be denied a final appearance at Lord's today after sustaining an injury prior to West Indies' opening match in the NatWest Triangular Series on Thursday.
fields.body:
Courtney Walsh could be denied a final appearance at Lord's today after sustaining an injury prior to West Indies' opening match in the NatWest Triangular Series on Thursday.

The 37-year-old fast bowler was due to start against England as West Indies attempt to bounce back from the demoralising Test defeat at the same venue and their opening triangular defeat by Zimbabwe in Bristol, but a problem with his instep threatens his participation.

'He's been having problems and has gone for a scan,' said captain Jimmy Adams. 'I saw him attempting to bowl at Bristol, but it caused him a lot of discomfort.'

In the County Championship, Yorkshire's batsmen continued their dismal form. Playing on the same Headingley pitch on which they made more than 500 earlier in the season, the leaders were dismissed for 129 against Durham, with only three batsmen reaching double figures. Left-armer Simon Brown lead the way with four wickets for 33.

Forced to follow on, the hosts were 9 without loss at close, 176 behind.

The resurgent England all-rounder Dominic Cork brought his Test match form with him to give Derbyshire the upper hand against Lancashire at the Racecourse Ground. He took six for 41, with his first victim his England colleague Michael Atherton for a duck, and he also dismissed Indian Test batsman Saurav Ganguly.

Lancashire struggled to 172 narrowly to avoid the follow-on, and they then kept hope just about alive by taking two Derbyshire wickets for 40 by stumps.

Warwickshire's Ashley Giles is in a rare run of form at present and he followed up his 98 in the first innings at Edgbaston on Thursday with six Sussex wickets for 58.

The Second Division leaders were 25 for one at close - a lead of 119.

fields.headline: Surrey top of the class
fields.standfirst: Surrey batsmen teach Leicestershire a lesson on school's exquisite batting surface
fields.trailText: Surrey's batsmen teach Leicestershire a lesson on school's exquisite batting surface
fields.body:
It was in 1938 that Brian Valentine of Kent made the highest first-class score on this ground, 242, after which there was no more county cricket at the school. One can imagine that Leicestershire were a bit fed up with blighters coming from elsewhere to fill their boots on this lovely batting surface. If that was so, the home side must be fed up again. The first county game here in 62 years saw Surrey's Alistair Brown cruise past Valentine's record, then go beyond his own personal best of 265 as well, before finishing 295 not out.

Even No.11, Saqlain Mushtaq, was able to register a championship best when he went past 45. He outpaced Brown, succeeding with a number of bravura strokes, as the pair added a punishing 141 for the last wicket.

Then, this seemingly unequal contest - albeit between teams placed third and fourth in the first division - was dramatically exaggerated as the home side lost seven wickets in the half-session before tea. Now the record books were being checked for 'lowest' totals on this ground. In the end, the Foxes managed to just avoid that record.

To all but diehard Leicestershire members, the pitch was a triumph for the school groundsman, Keith Exton. Even in a week of difficult weather he was able to unveil a surface that was a pale bis cuit colour: well grassed but dry and firm. Yesterday morning, with the tail-enders accompanying Brown looking just as much at home as the man who had passed 200, it was clear the pitch had become a batting heaven.

Indeed, the ground had a heavenly aspect: an ocean of green, perfectly level and with boundaries set at the maximum 90 metres. But when fieldsmen thought the extra space enabled them to get around and save a boundary the ball simply fled from them.

Even Saqlain was able to start by pushing drives that travelled as if across a billiards baize, deceptively making pace through the gaps. Later, buzzing with confidence, he jumped out to slog the occasional medium pace of Darren Maddy. Meanwhile Brown proceeded sedately. There were a couple of lovely cover drives early on, and the odd dismissive pull. Otherwise it was mostly easy singles. Finally, Vince Wells took what had become the vital wicket - the last one - as Saqlain, on 66, was bowled through a loose stroke. Even Anil Kumble, a world record-holder, got not a single wicket.

Now, on a fine pitch, the home batsmen were challenged to answer a big total with one of their own. Like so many other sides this season they were conspicuously unable to. With Martin Bicknell and Alex Tudor bowling a good line and moving the ball away, three batsmen soon edged to the slips - among them, Aftab Habib first ball.

On and on it went. The slow exit of batsmen signified irritation with themselves underlined by despair at their collective situation. From 51 for seven Neil Burns and DeFreitas doubled the score, their convincing despatch of the bad ball confirming the pitch quality, before DeFreitas was taken at silly point. By now the spinners were on. Given moderate weather, they look likely to engineer a sizeable victory - big enough, perhaps, to set yet another record on the old ground.

fields.headline: ICC look at Lara logo
fields.trailText: Brian Lara is unique among cricketers. Other batsmen may endorse, say, Slazenger or Gunn & Moore. But on the front of his blue 'scoop' bat the single name Lara signifies the fact that the batsman is the company. And that could cause some difficulty for him, and for the International Cricket Council.
fields.body:
Brian Lara is unique among cricketers. Other batsmen may endorse, say, Slazenger or Gunn & Moore. But on the front of his blue 'scoop' bat the single name Lara signifies the fact that the batsman is the company. And that could cause some difficulty for him, and for the International Cricket Council.

The concern of the ICC has centred on the likelihood of so-called 'commercial' logos on individual players' bats conflicting with those of match or team sponsors. Accordingly, the decision has been made to ban commercial logos, whilst leaving makers' logos (eg Slazenger's panther) relatively unrestricted. But awkward questions now arise - questions to which the ICC were unable to respond last week. Are the names of cigarette brands on Indian players' bats really going to be stopped by the ICC or, on their behalf, by the Indian board?

If a sub-division of Wills, say, is set up to sell even a handful of bats, does that qualify them to be a bat manufacturer? Or do they need to physically make them? The ICC must decide on a definition as they try to construct a list of 'recognised manufacturers'. They will be aware that the Brian Lara company does not make bats any more than supermarkets make their own-brand baked beans. And if Brian Lara is ruled not to be a recognised bat manufacturer he is, presumably, a non-approved 'commercial' name. It's looking like a good batting wicket for the lawyers.

Judging from the prices, a memorabilia web-site set up by broadcaster Charles Colville looks like making some serious money for cricketers. Top of the list is a painting of Lord's by the cricketer-artist Martin Speight, which is offered at £10,000. If realised, that would place it among the highest sum ever paid for a contemporary cricket painting.

If that's beyond your purse, the www.cricketmemo.com site offers John Emburey's blazers from the 1982 and 1990 rebel tours of South Africa for £600 and £500 respectively. And Emburey's tie from the 1990 tour can be had for £100.

From Cornhill, through Axa, Norwich Union and PPP Healthcare, insurance companies continue to dominate cricket sponsorship. But it's PPP who seem to attempt the obvious and sell policies direct to cricketers.

In a scheme set up with Surrey, constituent clubs have been offered incentives to persuade members to take out policies. The club is rewarded with a cash injection of about £120 a year in respect of each policy, while the policy will cost the holder £650 a year. Whether this idea leads to a surge of new business remains to be seen.

webTitle: Time for Fifa to put order in their house

fields.headline: Time for Fifa to put order in their house
fields.trailText: Just because the International Olympic Committee has traditionally run its affairs in a shamelessly feudal fashion is no reason for football to follow suit.
fields.body:
Enough has been said already about the World Cup 2006 decision, which was clearly stitched up in Germany's favour around the time England got the go-ahead for Euro 96, just as everyone outside the amnesiac FA and deserving but naive South Africa originally assumed.

Of course it is a great shame that grubby politics and Eurocentric self-interest should prevail at the expense of taking the game around the world - not to mention the fact that the gift of a World Cup ended up in the trembling hands of a 78-year-old from a hotbed of football like New Zealand - but attempting to rationalise a shambolic system only invests the ludicrous bid process with an importance it does not deserve. Might as well complain that the best song does not always win the Eurovision Song Contest, or that some pretty ropey films end up with Oscars.

Just because the International Olympic Committee has traditionally run its affairs in a shamelessly feudal fashion is no reason for football to follow suit. The IOC is putting its house in order in any case after the Salt Lake City scandals, but as the Olympic Games only demand attention for a few weeks every four years then disappear from the public consciousness for the next 47 months, one can at least understand why administrators like to maximise every publicity opportunity.

Football is not like that. The game occupies most of the world's attention most of the time. World Cups are guaranteed successes, that's why everybody wants one, and also why Fifa has a duty to distribute them fairly, systematically and, above all, transparently.

No one beyond bid committees, Fifa bureaucrats and a handful of dogged journalists has the remotest interest in the boring details of how World Cups are handed out. All football followers want to know is where the next one is going to be, so they can forget about it until nearer the time. One suspects South Africa will not forget recent events in a hurry, however, and hopefully all the thoroughly deserved bad publicity will force Fifa into a rethink. They are already talking about rotation, but that's nothing new. The general principle of rotation is supposedly in force already. What is needed is to put it into operation not just for the next World Cup, or the one after that, but in 20 or 24 yearly cycles with each zone or continent getting a turn and each knowing precisely, and plenty of time in advance, when its turn will come round.

fields.headline: Cancer charity attacked over 'shock' advert
fields.standfirst: Alarmist and irresponsible, say critics
fields.trailText: The advertisement seems harmless enough. Three young girls join in a gentle embrace. Each has a label - 'lawyer', 'teacher' and 'cancer' over their heads - with an Imperial Cancer Research Fund logo at the top of the page. Yet it has provoked fury, amid claims it is misleading the public about cancer.
fields.body:
The advertisement seems harmless enough. Three young girls join in a gentle embrace. Each has a label - 'lawyer', 'teacher' and 'cancer' over their heads - with an Imperial Cancer Research Fund logo at the top of the page.

The ad, published in several UK newspapers, including The Observer, is intended simply to raise awareness of the dangers of cancer, says the fund. Yet it has provoked widespread academic fury. Researchers, including some of the fund's own scientists, say it is alarmist and irresponsible, and accuse the fund of deliberately misleading the public about cancer.

Industry observers also fear it represents an escalation in the use of shock tactics by charities desperate to obtain dwindling public support. Recent examples of controversial fund-raising attempts include a Barnardo's advert of a baby injecting itself with heroin. Now the cancer charities appear to be adopting a similar approach.

'This cancer advert represents a return to the dark ages of health campaigning,' said Theresa Marteau, professor of health psychology at King's College, London. 'It shocks and threatens but at no point provides a chance for people to find sources of reassurance or information.

'The advert also gives out a dangerous message because it defines people by their disease. It says you do not have a job, just a role as a sick person. You are not a teacher or a lawyer, just a cancer.'

This criticism was backed by the broadcaster and cancer victim John Diamond: 'I am that third person, and I can think of any number of ways of describing myself - father, husband, journalist - before I thought to use that word to sum up just who I am.'

However, these claims were last week rejected by the fund, which also denied there had been any internal criticism of the advert - although it did admit it had received 'one or two complaints' from the public.

'We recently carried out a survey that showed 91 per cent of British people underestimate their chance of getting cancer at some time in their lives,' said Stacy Adams, the fund's director of communications. 'More than half of our interviewees thought their risk was one in 10 or less. In fact, it is one in three, and we have designed this very tasteful ad to make this point.'

However, researchers argue that it completely fails to achieve this goal. 'The ad suggests that one in three girls will get cancer, and that is not the case,' said Marteau. 'Cancer is primarily a disease of old age, and it affects men as much as women. You get no impression of this from the advert.

'More importantly, cancer is not inevitable, as the fund suggests. You can do things to reduce your risk, like giving up smoking.

'This advert offers no course of action or help. It simply shocks. It is overblown and it misrepresents the truth.'

Even the advert's aim of startling the public was questioned by Professor Steve Morley, of Leeds University's department of psychiatry.

'The shocking images which make a lasting impression are more usually associated with experiences in our own lives or even with some bigger national event - not a photograph of unknown people,' he said.

Nevertheless, the fund's medical director John Toy insisted the advert was successful. 'Yes, there is a lot you can do to prevent cancer, but we simply wanted to show the disease is a lot more common than people seem to think.'

fields.headline: Boring? It's hip and hot
fields.standfirst: John Brunton  on the finest eating, shopping and clubbing in an elegant city teeming with irreverent life
fields.trailText: John Brunton on the finest eating, shopping and clubbing in an elegant city teeming with irreverent life
fields.body:
While Belgians may think that their capital is well on its way to being the recognised first city of a future Euroland, it is not in many people's Top Ten of destinations for a fun weekend. Brussels has pretty boring reputation. We Brits tend to think of it as inhabited by a vast army of faceless, overpaid Eurocrats, who spend their time dreaming up senseless laws to annoy everyone, while the Belgians have never escaped their dour image of people who eat 'mussels and frites', drink lots of beer and read Tintin comics. So it is a shock to discover that it is one of the Continent's best kept secrets: a vibrant, exciting city, seething with creativity. The kind of place where, for once, checking out the shopping, restaurants and nightlife will take a lot more of your time than the classic sightseeing of museums and monuments.

Walk into a shop here and people are already talking prices in euros rather than Belgian francs. The language they're talking might well be English, Spanish or Italian, rather than the official native tongues of French and Flemish. People here are used to foreigners, and are friendly, irreverent and welcoming. And whether you are drinking in one of the hundreds of bars, browsing in fashionable designer boutiques, wandering through the many flea markets or dancing to frenetic techno music in a nightclub, you are bound to end up getting to know locals who are better than any guidebook at explaining their city.

Any visit must kick off in La Grande Place, one of the world's most beautiful and grandest squares, lined with exquisite Baroque and Gothic architecture and dozens of fun cafés. Tourists then tend to head into the adjoining Rue des Bouchers, a narrow, cobbled street awash with neon signs, extravagant displays of lobsters, prawns, oysters and crabs, and waiters desperate to tempt in potential customers. Resist the temptation, and let the tour groups go on inevitably to the daft, minuscule Mannekin Pis statue. This is the moment to start discovering the insider's Brussels.

SHOPPING

1 Elvis Pompiello

60 Rue du Midi

Elvis is the King of Belgian haute couture hat-makers, and his stylish boutique has everything from pink sequined top hats to exquisite feather and taffeta creations. When he puts on one of his wild fashion shows, seductively-dressed live models sit in the shop windows, causing crowds to jam the pavement. Don't miss the outrageous pink interior of the hat store opposite, S2.

2 Chez Ramon & Valy

19 Rue des Teinturiers

At first sight, this colourful showroom looks like any other fun second-hand clothes shop. But banish thoughts of Oxfam, as these two young Spanish designers, Ramona and Valy, have their own craft atelier, and specialise in reworking cast-off garments into highly original one-off outfits. Fashion shopping only begins here, as just around the corner is Rue Antoine Dansaert, the home of cutting-edge Belgian designers, from internationally renowned Dries Van Noten, to local newcomers such as Nicolas Voit and Patrick Pitschin.

3 Bali-Africa

154 Rue Blaes

Rue Blaes is one of the many streets in Brussels lined with dozens of antique and junk shops. It is a bargain- hunter's paradise. Nothing, however, quite prepares you for this tumbledown warehouse, teeming with affordable collectables from Africa, Asia and Latin America, which is run by a genial Balinese, who speaks perfect English. You soon lose yourself in a vast warren of tiny rooms filled to bursting with thousands of masks, statues, spears, jewellery, paintings and carved wooden furniture. If you want more elegant, art deco design, walk up to Rue Haute, where two shops, Jacques Brol (number 202) and the adjacent Bruxelles Intimes, have an irresistible selection.

4 Sunday markets

Place du Jeu de Balle

It is easy to believe that everyone in Brussels devotes their Sunday mornings to wandering through the city's packed markets. Just by the Midi station, a dozen streets are overrun by what is called the Exotique Market. More Morocco than Belgium, it has noisy vendors hawking olives, fragrant oranges, fresh herbs and pungent spices. Over in the Place du Grand Sablon, a more chic crowd browse through expensive, but high quality antiques. But on the sprawling Place du Jeu de Balle stands what must be the ultimate flea market. Hundreds of packed stalls form a vast, chaotic myriad of bric-a-brac, curios, hidden treasures and pure rubbish. You'll end up spending hours sifting through all the wares.

5 Kaat Tilley

4 Galérie du Roi

The ultimate spot for chic shopping is the grandiose Galéries St Hubert, three iron- and glass-covered arcades built in 1846, which are a majestic monument to a time when Belgium was still a major colonial power. Smart families sit out on café terraces, the traditional Taverne Henri serves the city's best moules frites , while chocolate lovers from all over the world head for the stately showroom of the Neuhaus family, who invented the praline . But the most enticing spot is the mystical boutique of leading young designer Kaat Tilley. She creates dreamy, romantic dresses, presented in an equally fairytale decor. And prices are a lot lower than for something as original in London.

EATING OUT

6 Le Petit Boxeur

3 Borgval, tel: 02 511 4000

Dining out is one of the most appealing aspects of this eclectic city, and this is typified by the hip, new restaurant, Le Petit Boxeur, in the heart of the bohemian St Catherine neighbourhood. The decor is tasteful and romantic - candles burning everywhere - the cuisine an inventive melange of French and Italian influences. There is, for instance, a 'lasagne' of squid stuffed with tuna and mussels, or sautéed snails on a bed of stinging nettles with basalmic vinegar - all complemented by an impressive, if expensive, wine list. Booking is essential.

7 Lola

33 Place du Grand Sablon, tel O2 514 2460

This smart, airy dining room - all pastel colours and minimalist furniture - wouldn't be out of place in New York's SoHo, especially with its open kitchen, where the chefs perform their skills in front of diners. The dishes are equally innovative, including an incredible raw foie gras accompanied by a warm lentil salad, and duck roasted in mango. Great for Saturday or Sunday lunch, as it looks out over the lively, weekend Grand Sablon antiques market.

8 Hémisphères

65 Rue de l'Ecuyer, tel: 02 513 9370

This is the perfect spot for lunch after shopping in the nearby Galéries St Hubert. Be prepared for surprises, though, as you walk into what looks like an exotic harem salon with the feel of a Middle Eastern souk. Diners lounge on battered velvet sofas, waitresses rush between tables carrying steaming glasses of mint tea and huge plates of half a dozen different appetisers. The chef prepares most of the dishes at a huge table at the end of the restaurant, and his speciality is a great couscous.

9 Bonsoir Clara

22 Rue Antoine Dansaert, tel: 02 502 0990

Even if you reserve a table in advance, be prepared to wait a while, as Bonsoir Clara, in the middle of the fashion district, is the hottest spot in town now - the place everyone wants to be seen in. Luckily it has a classy cocktail bar in which customers can while away the time. The decor of multi-coloured stained glass is stunning, the atmosphere electric, and fortunately the American-style fusion cuisine is pretty good too. The best news is that this is one of the few spots open on a Sunday evening, ensuring a good end to a Brussels weekend.

10 La Tentation

28 Rue de Laecken, tel: 02 537 4547

This is a venue which completely changes personality between lunchtime and the evening. Entrepreneurs have transformed a cavernous abandoned warehouse into what is, ostensibly, a centre for Galician culture. You can do everything here: drink at the city's longest bar, have a cheap lunch buffet of Spanish tapas, enjoy a more gastronomic meal in the evening of specialities from Galicia, then move into party mode, when you'll see people on the dance floor doing the tango and the flamenco, and whirling to wild Gypsy violins and wailing Celtic bagpipes. Coming out onto the street, its hard to believe you're in Belgium!

BARS & NIGHTLIFE

11 L'Archiduke

6 Rue Antoine Dansaert

This is the best bar in Brussels, but don't expect to find it in many guide books, as loyal locals are determined to keep it for themselves rather than put it on the tourist bar- crawl circuit. Resembling a Fifties New York jazz dive, L'Archiduke is chic without being pretentious, though you have to ring an outside buzzer to be allowed in. The barman shakes a perfect dry Martini, and most evenings there are cool concerts by a fine jazz trio.

12 A La Mort Subite

7 Rue Montagne-aux-Herbes Potageres

Belgians love drinking beer, and although the city has more than its fair share of ancient watering holes, such as A la Becasse, Au Bon Vieux Temps and A L'Imaige Nostre-Dame, the Mort Subite has become more of an institution than a simple bar. Nothing has changed here for a century - the prices chalked on huge mirrors, the wood-panelled walls yellowed with smoke, the primly dressed waitresses balancing huge mugs of foaming beer. The Mort Subite - or sudden death - is also the name of a beer, though the best beverage to order is a slightly cloudy 'lambic', light and freshly fermented.

13 La Fleur en Papier Doré

53 Rue des Alexiens

Brussels's most famous citizen was the famed surrealist painter, René Magritte, and his favourite haunt was this equally surreal tavern, whose name in English is the Flower of Golden Paper. Founded in 1846 by a religious order, Les Soeurs de Charité, this 'estaminet' - the dialect word for a bar - became a meeting place for painters in the Twenties. The three tiny salons are still decorated with scores of Dadaist paintings and surrealist poems hand-written on the wall. Apart from dozens of different beers, it also serves some fine wines and probably the best onion soup you have ever tasted.

14 La Java

31 Rue St Gery

After midnight, the Brussels nightlife can get pretty wild, especially in the dozens of bars that cram the fashionable St Catherine's quarter. The young head for the Bizon bar in Rue du Pont de la Carpe, live reggae bands play in L'Antrephil in the Rue du Vieux Marche aux Graines. But to get in party mode, kick off at La Java, which gets so packed that customers look as though they'll burst through the big glass windows. The barman doubles as the DJ between hurling the cocktail shaker up in the air.

15 Fuse

208 Rue Blaes

There's no lack of choice for late night dancing, but the one spot not to be missed is the Fuse. This is the mythical venue where techno music - Belgium's most questionable gift to the world - was born. Clubbing in Brussels is democratic, with few unpleasant bouncers vetting who is to be allowed in, cheap entrance prices, and drinks that never cost more than a couple of pounds, no matter how late it is. The Fuse doesn't really get going till after two in the morning. The best news of all is that there are three dance floors on different levels. The largest, of course, is for techno, but there is also one for house and another for chilling out to jazzy funk.

The barman doubles as the DJ between hurling the cocktail shaker up in the air. 15 Fuse 208 Rue Blaes There's no lack of choice for late night dancing, but the one spot not to be missed is the Fuse. This is the mythical venue where techno music - Belgium's most questionable gift to the world - was born. Clubbing in Brussels is democratic, with few unpleasant bouncers vetting who is to be allowed in, cheap entrance prices, and drinks that never cost more than a couple of pounds, no matter how late it is. The Fuse doesn't really get going till after two in the morning. The best news of all is that there are three dance floors on different levels. The largest, of course, is for techno, but there is also one for house and another for chilling out to jazzy funk.

webTitle: If you're heading Stateside, the tip is: don't forget to tip

fields.headline: If you're heading Stateside, the tip is: don't forget to tip
fields.standfirst: Travel news
fields.trailText: Travel news.
fields.body:
Seasoned travellers have a top tip for millions of British holidaymakers arriving at US airports this summer: 'Have a roll of $1 notes handy.' Americans are dedicated to tipping, as London taxi drivers will tell you, so everyone from porters at airports to hotel maids expects their fair share.

But British travellers often have problems grasping the intricacies of tipping in the US, after a long flight, and fail to understand how many people who help them on their way are expecting a few notes in return.

This is not helped when a stressed out father, for instance, digs into his pocket to pull out his dollars and finds nothing smaller than a $50 note. Confusion and embarrassment reign. Sue Ockwell of Discover New England, which promotes six US states, says: 'It is difficult, particularly if you haven't been there before. British people don't understand how low the wages are for US service staff and how much they rely on tipping,' she says.

There was outrage when Britons started hitting the ski slopes in the resort of Breckenridge because so few tips were handed out. Across America, waiting staff deprived of tips are even known to pursue customers down the street.

Some UK tour operators include tipping suggestions in their departure information, and passengers on US cruise ships often find a guide to tipping in their cabins. But keeping up with the tipping trends means staying up to date with the latest changes. Regular traveller Jo Malone, from Norwich, says: 'Tipping in US restaurants seems to be going up all the time. Last time I went to America it was 15 per cent, now I've been told you are expected to pay 20.'

But it's not all bad news: the prospect of a tip can bring better service. Ockwell says that in Vermont recently she gave a $5 tip to a hotel staff member who helped her find a UK plug adapter and 'he was delighted'.

As a rule of thumb, porters, red caps or anyone who helps with bags would expect a tip of $1 per bag and hotel maids expect $1 a day, which can be left in an envelope in your room. Other hotel staff who expect a tip include a concierge who books tickets for a show and a doorman who hails a taxi.

To add to the confusion, Britons can also be flummoxed by various travel taxes not quoted on a menu or hotel room rate, but found on the final bill. Restaurant taxes are different in every US state, so in Anaheim, California, home of Disneyland, it is 7.75 per cent, but in Orlando, home of Disney World, Florida, it is 6 per cent. Hotel tax changes by state too: so 15 per cent will be added to your hotel bill in Anaheim, but in Orlando it is only 11 per cent. No wonder tourists get confused.

There may be light at the end of the tipping tunnel: some new hotels in the US, including the Seaport Hotel in Boston, have introduced a no tipping rule. It will be no surprise if its popularity with Britons suddenly soars.

fields.headline: Go for it
fields.standfirst: Late bargains
fields.trailText: Late bargains.
fields.body:
Holidays

Ireland

Galway, on Ireland's wild west coast, is limbering up for its annual Arts Festival beginning 18 July. Acts range from traditional music concerts to Steppenwolf. Prices for four-night stays at the nearby Connemara Gateway Hotel with Cresta Holidays (0870 161 0910) start at £310 per person for the festival period and include Seacat crossings from Liverpool to Dublin. For a festival schedule, check www.galwayartsfestival.com.

Corfu

Thomas Cook (0870 751 9927) is offering a seven-night self catering holiday on the island that inspired Gerald and Lawrence Durrell for £259 per person, a saving of £150. Departures are from Luton Airport on 17July.

Hotels

Le Meridien Hotels is offering savings of up to 50 per cent off room rates at more than 125 city and resort hotels until 31 August in its Le Passport summer promotion. Reservations can be made on 0800 028 2840.

France

Save 15 per cent on a selection of cottages and villas during July and August with French Life (0113 239 0077). One week at Poulidore, a restored farmhouse with swimming pool in the Aquitaine region, sleeping nine, is £1,176 (a saving of £200). The price includes return ferry crossings with a car. Bowhills is also offering a range of last-minute deals on French properties, including one week at a Provençal villa near Montpellier for £225 per person. Call 01489 872727 for details.

Peru and Bolivia

Encounter (020 7370 6845) has reduced the cost of its 26-day Incas and Andes trip through Peru and Bolivia by £100. The new price of £1,170 includes land transport, meals, accommodation and guides, but flights are extra. The tour departs on 21 August and takes in Machu Picchu and Lake Titicaca.

Italy

Although the Italian Renaissance cruise starts and ends in Palma, as the name suggests, the itinerary mainly features Italian destinations, including Rome, Naples and Sicily. Malta and Sardinia are also ports of call. The cruise now costs £499 (a saving of £260 per person) and includes flights from Gatwick. Call Airtours on 08701 577775 for details.

Flights

Johannesburg

Book before 31 July with Trailfinders (020 7938 3939) for return flights to Johannes-burg for just £300, including pre-paid taxes.The flights are with Swissair and depart from either Heathrow or Manchester. All travel must be completed by 31 August and there is a minimum stay of seven days.
