webTitle: The greatest peep show on earth

fields.headline: The greatest peep show on earth
fields.standfirst: Where Tracey Emin led, Will Self followed. Now the ultimate in exhibitionism is C4's Big Brother, a programme in the vanguard of a new culture. Are we all voyeurs now?
fields.trailText: Where Tracey Emin led, Will Self followed. Now the ultimate in exhibitionism is C4's Big Brother, a programme in the vanguard of a new culture. Are we all voyeurs now?
fields.body:
In the early days of British television, Hughie Green bowed out of every show of Opportunity Knocks by turning to the camera and telling the viewers at home, most sincerely: 'Remember, it's your vote that counts.' It was the closest the viewer got to empowerment back in the Sixties and Seventies, beyond the interactivity of switching the set off. Shared experience is something else these days.

And the idea of putting the power in the hands of the viewer, while simultaneously removing the privacy of the viewed, is an idea that is beginning to dominate television and the surrounding territories. Later this month, a television programme makes the public privy to the kind of places that the camera has never before been granted access, while simultaneously claiming to put the viewer in control.

The event has been touted in some circles with the kind of zeal that accompanied the first footage of the Apollo Moon landings. But at the core of Big Brother is Hughie's first law - it really is your vote that counts. Sincerely. And this time, the stakes are high. This is not a vote that may lead to a impressionist getting top billing at Butlin's in high season. This is the kind of vote that could result in someone winning £70,000 or throwing themselves in front of a train.

'Never before have people consented to being filmed under close scrutiny for so long,' says Liz Warner, C4's commissioning editor for the series. 'It's the first time in the UK that the audience can be truly be involved and influence the destiny of the participants by voting for who stays and who goes.'

For nine weeks, 25 cameras and 30 microphones will watch over the every move of 10 volunteers, who have been selected from more than 40,000 applicants to live in a specially built house. Each will be subsidised by a daily fee of £30. Each week, the viewers vote on which member of the group is eliminated, until one emerges as the winner.

Big Brother takes our continuing preoccupation with voyeurism and exhibitionism into a new arena. The show is an attempt to transform exhibitionism from a voyeur's pastime into a viewer's sport. Exhibitionism is normally associated with things out of the ordinary. What's on show here is the sheer banality of ordinary lives.

Writing recently in the New York Times on the phenomenon, Marshall Sella made the point that exhibitionism is being marketed as a form of adventure: 'Exposure to media scrutiny is like being exposed to the elements. Only, the elements here are sight and sound, the heat of klieg lights instead of the sting of wind. We are asked to believe that this century's first explorers, our Scotts and Amundsens, are those who can withstand the pressures of the lens. Big Brother housemates travel down an Amazon of the self, unafraid to wash or weep [and not forgetting, please, to undress] in front of millions of strangers. And adversity, as everybody knows, breeds heroes.'

Here the hurdles are the ups and downs of living within a confined space, with people you hardly know, and without certain creature comforts. The questions that beg to be asked are at what point would the camera likely to be switched off? and how far would this go in the name of entertainment?

It's like the moment in The Truman Show when Jim Carrey's character turns violently on his wife to test if someone else is writing the script of his life. The production team look set to intervene. Laura Linney, the actress who plays his wife, shouts: 'You're so unprofessional.'

The participants emerging from the house of Big Brother abroad are treated like heroes, and immediately shrouded by a particular type of fame - the promise of recording contracts and modelling contracts, and the rounds of the chat-show circuit. This must be their prime motive for participating. It's a line that can be traced back to the strand on The Word, in which members of the studio audience would do anything to get on television.

But this is not simply a few minutes with an old man's dentures in your mouth in the name of notoriety, but a crowd of cameras and a cast of millions - C4 has high hopes - potentially witnessing your every move. The game of fame has changed. During In Bed With Madonna , Warren Beatty pointed out that the singer saw no point in doing anything unless she did it on camera. There are now members of the general public that will take the same approach, knowing that the rewards may be great, but aware, equally, that it is a kind of game and that each round brings them closer to the prize.

What distinguishes Big Brother from the idea within The Truman Show is that whereas Truman was oblivious to his predicament, players within this show willingly hand over their privacy.

An example of a programme that put 24-hour surveillance and hidden cameras to good use rather than simply letting the lens ogle and loiter was last week's The Secret Life of the Family. A hybrid emerging from the BBC's Science and Features departments, this was in its own way a deeper and more radical probe into the everyday lives of a group of people than Big Brother. The documentary was the stuff of education entertainment and horror as it homed in on the bug life that existed within the hair and clothes of an average family.

For the viewers of Big Brother, this programme is another chance to play God. But it's the networks that have most to gain, from the convergence of confessional culture and new media. In the light of the success of these shows abroad, networks here are now fighting for the next one out of the factory, in the way that was previously the case with docu-soaps. The latest, The Mole, was the talk of this year's Montreux Television Festival. The format was quickly snapped up by Channel 5.

The two themes that dominate, that of a level of interactivity within the grasp of the audience, and an elimination of privacy on the part of the subject, are currently found away from the camera, and in art and performance.

Last month, novelist Will Self spent the best part of a week in the window of a London gallery, with nothing more than a computer and sunglasses that looked better on the Velvets. Every day, he wrote a story based around the characters who showed up to watch him, in order to witness the writer at work and be his muse.

What better way to make someone read a story than to put them in it? But ultimately it was the novelty of the method, rather than the content of the result that seemed of interest. Previously, Tracey Emin had spent nine days in the nude painting and drawing in a gallery window as the world wandered by and commented.

If the voyeurism and exhibitionism of Big Brother has an equivalent in the art world, Emin is it: a variation on a the lapdancer offering everything up for intimate scrutiny as the middle- class, middle-age men of the art world metaphorically stuff money in her knickers and dream of being in her unmade bed. Ultimately, for most of those coming to watch Emin, it was still essentially a woman with her breasts out. Just as, despite the mutterings of Big Brother being a social experiment, the sole reason for most people tuning in will be the prospect of witnessing relative strangers embroiled in a feud or a fuck. Millions of viewers in Holland tuned in to see two become one, under a blanket in the Big Brother house. The infra-red lighting revealing the blurry images added to the seediness of the whole episode.

Finally, the TV viewer had become like a punter at a peep show. As a showcase for what happy bedfellows the internet, television and the concept of the interactive viewer could become, at the most fundamental level, Big Brother is the perfect vehicle. Ultimately, there is too little time within a television programme to ponder the banality of ordinary lives in the manner of CCTV scanning the forecourt of a petrol station.

Something needs to happen, and in order to make it happen, something unreal has to be placed in the situation to create a narrative and the drama. In this instance, something has to be taken away. These characters are surrounded, and captured on film, by state-of-the-art technology, but they have to exist without the fundamental tools of communication - telephones, computers, television, faxes - that signpost their daily lives. This immediately makes the whole concept once removed from being the reality television that it claims to be.

However, the internet makes it possible to wait and witness everything that happens, unabridged, and in real time. Outside the regular visits to the house on C4, there is the website to which everyone has access to all that's happening on the cameras all day and all night.

The network has already attempted something similar with last year's Smart Hearts . Long after the pilot was over, it was possible to look at the programme's website to catch up on the instalments in this real-life soap in which a man, for the sake of the camera, lived with his ex-girlfriend and his current girlfriend. If Big Brother is, on one level, a webcam show for television, its internet site will take you to the parts that the TV show cannot reach, although television provided the platform for fans of the show to be privy to one of the participants going through their motions in the lavatory.

'Exactly 21 frames went out on the air,' according to Paul Romer, one of the creators of Big Brother . 'That's less than one second. It shouldn't have been possible. But everything goes wrong at the same time. Someone is in there, and she is using the toilet paper at that instant, and two million people are watching.'

Apparently, the reasons for the cameras being installed in the toilet were those of health and safety. Foreign producers expressed concerns that someone could keel over or fall victim to a heart attack while relieving themselves.

There is a reason for making a programme that probes privacy in order to discover more about health issues and maybe even turn up some relevant forensic evidence that could ultimately bring about change, but that certainly isn't true of Big Brother .

If Big Brother is a success here, within the realms of television and the internet, a further series would be expected to involve the viewer even more, in the manner of certain types of webcam pages. Not simply a case of choosing when someone is eliminated, but choosing when they defecate, fornicate, masturbate.

Of course, to stay in the game, they'll have to comply. Remember, it's your vote that counts.

 Big Brother can be seen from 14 July at www.channel4.com/bigbrother, with a one-hour special on C4 on 18 July

webTitle: Zoff undone by Berlusconi's indecent proposal

fields.headline: Zoff undone by Berlusconi's indecent proposal
fields.trailText: How the AC Milan supremo saw off the man who took Italy to the final of Euro 2000.
fields.body:
I can snap my fingers and require the rain from a clear blue sky and turn it off again

'Silvio' - Bob Dylan

Was Bob Dylan contemplating Silvio Berlusconi when he wrote those lines in 1988? ' Non importante ', as the Italians would say, given the prophetic nature of art. For the lyric fits Berlusconi like a Savile Row suit, as he proved to smashing effect last week, felling Italy's 'gentle giant,' the just-deemed-heroic-after-all national team manager, Dino Zoff, with the force of a single declarative sentence.

'I am indignant,' Berlusconi declared. 'I repeat, I am indignant.' He added details, saying that Italy's play in the Euro 2000 final had been either 'unworthy' or 'disgraceful', depending on how one chose to translate; that even an amateur would have known enough to man-mark Zinedine Zidane, and that, 'one either has intelligence in his head or does not,' making it clear on which pile of skulls he placed Zoff's.

It did not matter that Berlusconi's criticism was inane. (His own Demetrio Albertini of AC Milan had been assigned to mark Zidane in the final, and had done so to considerable effect).

Nor did it matter that the 'amateur' Zoff - who, as a player, had appeared in 570 Serie A matches (winning six championships during his 11 seasons with Juventus), plus a record 112 for the national team (culminating with victory in the 1982 World Cup), and who as a Serie A manager, first with Juventus and then with Lazio, won the Uefa Cup twice - had come within 30 seconds of capturing the European Championship last Sunday with a team many had not expected to survive the first round.

All that mattered was that Berlusconi had spoken. Because, in Italy, when Berlusconi speaks, the earth moves. Thus, the next morning, Zoff announced his resignation, saying, 'It would be difficult to continue, given the prominence of Mr Berlusconi.'

It is not easy for citizens of the outside world (ie any country beyond the borders of Italy) to grasp just how strong the nexus is between football and politics in that Republic. But a political science textbook could be written on the mileage Berlusconi has had from his early and acute awareness of the link.

From co-opting the fans' long-standing cheer for the national team - ' Forza Italia! ' - by using it as the name of his own right-wing political party, to converting AC Milan fan clubs around the country into Forza Italia party headquarters, Berlusconi has managed, through association with football, to override to a remarkable degree the abundant evidence of his own nefariousness.

For years Berlusconi's Fininvest holding company had been under criminal investigation, and he personally was convicted on two counts of bribery and extortion (overturned last spring by an appeals court) while his brother, Paolo, was sent to prison following conviction on similar charges.

Yet Berlusconi, who now owns almost every television station in Italy not under direct government control, as well as one national newspaper ( Il Giornale ), and the major publishing house, Mondadori, and who has minions highly-placed in the editorial hierarchies of many other major media outlets, plans to regain the office of Prime Minister in next year's general election when he quite reasonably expects to topple the ludicrously weak left-centre coalition now clinging to power by a thumbnail.

And so, last week, he chose to flex his muscles at Zoff's expense. He fully anticipated the wave of outrage at his remarks, and the immediate outpouring of sympathy for Zoff. For 24 hours, the former cruise-ship crooner danced backwards across the ring, saying, 'I have never given offence to anyone,' and 'If Zoff resigns, it must be for other reasons.'

And then, blindly pursued by his political enemies, who should have known better than to tackle him on football grounds, he slammed his trap shut.

'Who were these people who rushed to Zoff's defence?' he asked rhetorically, only hours after Zoff had glumly reaffirmed his resignation. 'They are of the political left. And they are so weak, and their grip on control so feeble, that they must resort to using a football manager as a means of attacking me.'

Notwithstanding that it was 180 degrees removed from what had actually occurred, this portrayal of Berlusconi as near-victim of yet another failed leftist plot - with Zoff cast in the most unlikely role of Che Guevara - was duly presented over his airwaves and by the many print journalists whom he controls.

By Thursday, Zoff was not only gone but forgotten, as Giovanni Trappatoni - not only the most successful active manager in Italy today, but a Berlusconi loyalist, as Zoff was not - was named to direct the national team.

Game, set, and match to Silvio.

One snap of the fingers brings the rain; the next clears the skies immediately. But Berlusconi has now moved beyond even Bob Dylan's range. At this point, only the deeper talent of a Verdi might capture him whole. The opera could be called La Travestia . How sad that in Italy the indecent always triumphs in the end.

fields.headline: Fans savage new football watchdog
fields.trailText: Plans for football's first-ever watchdog are in disarray amid mounting evidence that the body which is meant to clean up the game will be a toothless talking-shop.
fields.body:
Plans for football's first-ever watchdog are in disarray amid mounting evidence that the body which is meant to clean up the game will be a toothless talking-shop.

The establishment of the new Independent Football Commission has been surrounded by fierce rows between the Government, fan groups and the football authorities, especially the Premier League, over who should be on it and what powers it should have.

Although the new organisation will be billed as a major breakthrough when it is unveiled in the near future, fans are set to renounce it as 'weak and irrelevant' and a 'betrayal' of the plans for a proper 'Ombudsfan' agreed by a clear majority of the Football Task Force.

'The way it's being envisaged, it will be more of a football lapdog than a watchdog,' said one critic. 'We will have nothing to do with it, and nobody will believe that it is a meaningful body which will make things better for fans.'

However, inquiries by The Observer have established that:

* The Premier League has vetoed the appointment of several heavyweight figures who it feared would be too tough on issues such as ticketing and merchandise.

* Sir John Smith, the retired senior policeman who football hoped would give the IFC much-needed credibility, is unlikely to serve on it. He believes that without those deemed unacceptable by the Premier League_ - the former chairman of the Football Supporters Association Rogan Taylor and Labour peer Lord Richard Faulkner, deputy chairman of the task force - it will have little chance of establishing itself as a serious body with real clout.

* Supporters' organisations have been squeezed out of the process of selecting the members, despite an FA pledge that all prospective commissioners should be accepted to be 'independent by all parties'.

Fan groups have complained that the appointment of former Cabinet Minister Jack Cunningham as chairman of the new body is unwise because of his close links with Newcastle United, who alienated many people by forcing bond-holders to give up their pitch-side seats to accommodate new executive spectators.

In a move that could further compromise his 'independent' image, Cunningham may be paid a salary - perhaps £20,000 - by the Football Association.

The other names lined up as prospective members of the IFC are Brian Moore, the former ITV commentator; Deirdre Hutton, a consumer affairs specialist; Lord Taylor, a Tory peer; and, possibly, Sir John.

The FSA claims the Government has 'surrendered' in the face of pressure from the Premier League to water down the effectiveness of the new body.

fields.headline: FA Cup heads to Wales
fields.trailText: The FA Cup final will be played outside England for the first time, in the new home of Welsh rugby, while Wembley is shut for its £475 million transformation.
fields.body:
The FA Cup final will be played outside England for the first time, in the new home of Welsh rugby, while Wembley is shut for its £475 million transformation.

The game's showpiece fixture will be contested at Cardiff's Millennium Stadium in 2001, and probably for as long as Wembley is out of action. The FA believe the 73,000-seat arena in the Welsh capital is a more suitable location than Old Trafford or Twickenham.

The FA confirmed yesterday that Cardiff was its preferred venue. The Football League will follow suit in a few weeks by confirming that they will also stage their five big matches - the Worthington Cup final, three end-of-season divisional playoffs and Auto Windscreens Shield final - in Cardiff while Wembley is unavailable.

The FA believes it can rebuff criticism from traditionalists who object to England's biggest match of the season being played in another country, albeit temporarily, by stressing that Welsh clubs compete in the FA Cup too.

The Millennium Stadium, which opened in June 1999, hosted many matches in last autumn's Rugby World Cup and proved its suitability as a soccer venue six weeks ago when Wales-Brazil attracted a capacity crowd.

'The Millennium Stadium has established itself very quickly as a special venue', said the FA's David Davies.

Lancaster Gate believe that Twickenham's ongoing problems with its local residents and local council, who both object to non-rugby events being staged there, and the fact that Old Trafford is the home ground of serial Cup finalists Manchester United rule out the only two alternatives to have anything approaching Wembley's 78,000 capacity.

'Old Trafford is a great stadium but we can't go there because it's where one of England's leading clubs play. If United got to the final again, it would be a home fixture for them and we couldn't have that', explained an FA source. However, the league champions' 67,000-seat ground is sure to host some of England's matches during Wembley's redevelopment, which will be spread around different venues across the country.

'Cardiff has several advantages. It's not a club ground, it's a magnificent new stadium and because it's a national stadium, like Wembley, matches played there will retain the feeling that this is a huge event, something out of the ordinary, because there isn't a game played there every second week of the year', explained a League source.

The League believe many fans will not have to travel much further to Cardiff than if they were going to the Twin Towers in north London. The League also discussed staging the playoffs and Auto Windscreens Shield final at the homes of top Premier League clubs, none of whom could be involved in the games, before choosing Cardiff.

It is not yet clear if the Cardiff ground will also host both FA Cup semi-finals, as Wembley did this year and will do every year once it reopens. The FA may instead return to the tradition of holding those ties in a neutral ground.

Wembley has only held the Cup Final since the 1923 'White Horse Final'. Before then, since the competition began in 1871-72, it was played at Kennington Oval, south London; Lillee Bridge, near Stamford Bridge; Fallowfield athletics ground, Manchester; Goodison Park, Liverpool; Crystal Palace; Old Trafford; Stamford Bridge and then Wembley.

Wembley will close this autumn and is due to reopen in the spring of 2003. In all, around 20 football matches a year will have to be played elsewhere.

fields.headline: England 'never at the races'
fields.trailText: How Germany reacted to their World Cup bid success.
fields.body:
As England's World Cup bid team packed their bags and licked their wounds after another mauling on football's world stage, they would not have been consoled by the German verdict on another victory over England.

'Celebrating? Victory over England? Of course not,' said Thomas Schumann, sports editor of Stern magazine. 'We are celebrating victory, certainly, but not over England.You were not regarded as a serious threat - even before your hooligans went crazy in Belgium. There is no great job in winning this event over England . . . only in winning.'

It is tough when you discover that the horse you have backed was not quite the right strain of thoroughbred but, not only that, was never at the races in the first place. That is the way Schumann sees it - and the way he believes most Germans interpret it too.

'Everyone in Germany is delighted, of course,' he said. 'Because this was an unexpected triumph for us. All the media - tabloids, magazines, serious papers, and TV and radio are reacting like children at Christmas. This is a gift we didn't expect until probably about two hours before Sepp Blatter, the Fifa president, read out the word "Deutschland" from his envelope. In those last couple of hours leading up to the voting announcement, there was a growing sense that we might have won it.'

So how do Schumann, Stern and the German media believe Franz Beckenbauer and his bid team pulled off such an astonishing coup? 'We think it was a clever arrangement between the German Federation and the Asian delegates - Thailand, South Korea, Qatar and Saudi Arabia,' said Schumann. 'There is talk of a deal between Daimler-Chrysler, the Mercedes parent company, and Hyundai. This may be true but it has very little to do with football. It is politics and high finance of the highest order.

'The major TV stations here who are buying rights for the World Cup, paying some DM 3.4 billion for example, are desperate for a German team to play in the 2006 competition. Never has Germany's team looked so inept, but by winning the right to host the competition, the side are guaranteed to take place.'

So how do the victorious Germans view the disconsolate, disbelieving South Africans, so confident of victory until so late in the day? 'Germans pity the South Africans,' said Schumann. 'South Africa should have got the World Cup because nobody in Germany or in England really needs the World Cup. You, the English, hosted a great Euro 96 four years ago and we, too, have shown that we know how to organise these big tournaments. But here we did not really consider England an issue in the vote. Remember, England had broken their promise not to bid against Germany for this tournament and that did cause bad feeling. Now, I would expect Germany to back any Asian bid to hold the tournament in 2010 because of the backing Germany got from Asia.'

Did the Germans worry on Friday, as stories alleging bribery swept out of Zurich, that charges of corruption might snatch victory away from them? After all, Fifa did launch an immediate inquiry.

'Not really, we're too busy celebrating,' he admitted. 'The letters pushed under delegates' doors were obviously a hoax and by Friday afternoon the story broke in Germany that Titanic magazine - a little like Punch in Britain - had admitted sending these notes. The supposed sender, Martin Hanson, does not exist.'

What of Charles Dempsey, the 78-year-old delegate from New Zealand whose abstention in the final round of voting handed Germany their 12-11 victory? Had he backed South Africa, as his Oceania constituency demanded, Sepp Blatter's casting vote would have probably handed them the tournament.

'People here are saying that the greatest amount of pressure came from Blatter - he was desperate for 2006 to go to South Africa,' said Schumann. 'Dempsey had made it known that he would vote for England until their elimination and Germans believe it was wrong for Blatter to exert any pressure.'

And so is Germany prepared to host the event? How do the stadiums match up to England's? Is there the will to match the events hosted in Euro 88 and World Cup 74? 'Yes, there is, because unlike our failed bid to host the 2000 Olympics, there is major public backing for this event. Some 85 to 90 per cent of Germans are believed to be in favour. We have the political backing of government and some of the biggest businesses in the world.

'We're ready, no doubt, and the stadia will be rebuilt and refurbished. The Berlin Olympic Stadium will be refurbished; Hamburg is building a new stadium that will match the best in the world; and there is an impressive, major new stadium in Gelsenkirchen. We aren't quite matching England's stadia yet - but we will.'

And, apart from the obvious repercussions for South Africa and, indeed, England, Schumann reckons the backdraught from Thursday's vote will be felt most by Blatter. 'He is on very dangerous ground now,' said Schumann. 'There will undoubtedly be repercussions from this whole bidding process. Blatter wanted South Africa and he is a big loser. His job is safe until 2002 but then it looks as though he could lose that, too.'

There was even a hint of German humour in their reaction to victory in the bidding race. Titanic's editor, Martin Sonneborn, admitted his magazine's hoax and said their second fax to delegates promised Swatzwalder Schinken (German ham) and a cuckoo clock.

Meanwhile Der Spiegel's website reported: 'Charles Dempsey, the accomplished golfer who has frequently battled with Germany's World Cup bid boss Franz Beckenbauer on the golf course, will have to explain his actions to his Football Federation on Sunday.'

What could they be hinting at?

webTitle: A grey game on a grey day

fields.headline: A grey game on a grey day
fields.trailText: Watching this one-day international was about as exciting as, well, a wet weekend in St John's Wood. The sky was grey, the cricket was grey, and the result was grey: match abandoned and the points shared. Sky haven't really had much of a run for their money this year - the second Zimbabwe Test and three damp one-day squibs. Channel 4 will be sniggering into their beautifully coiffeured hairdos.
fields.body:
Watching this one-day international was about as exciting as, well, a wet weekend in St John's Wood. The sky was grey, the cricket was grey, and the result was grey: match abandoned and the points shared. Sky haven't really had much of a run for their money this year - the second Zimbabwe Test and three damp one-day squibs. Channel 4 will be sniggering into their beautifully coiffeured hairdos.

England had hobbled their way to 158 for 8 off 43.5 overs before rain finally killed the match. Marcus Trescothick and Graham Thorpe were the two beacons of light. Thorpe looked at ease and untroubled, though not always as urgent as he might have done. Trescothick, who gives the ball an amazing clout for somebody with such a non-existent backlift, was very happy-go-lucky. He's now made England's highest score in the two one-day internationals he has played in - not bad for an ingenu, even if he did play a silly stroke to get out to Chris Gayle.

Gayle, whose wiles amount to not spinning the ball at all, proved far too much for England. And Nasser Hussain, commenting on both Test Match Special and Sky, acknowledged that his batsmen have real problems against the slower bowlers. Maybe he will have an answer when he returns to the side later this week.

Craig White and Mark Ealham (who has never made a fifty in a one-day international) are batting a place too high at Nos. 6 and 7. They made rather a mess of the middle of the innings - insisting on nudging the ball square or backward of square rather than hitting over the top, which would have been far more demoralising for the bowler and more empowering for the batsmen.

They did do marginally better than poor Matthew Maynard, who offered no stroke at all to a Corey Collymore incutter. He jumped the queue when he was picked for yesterday's and today's games, but he runs the risk of returning to the county ranks swiftly. Vikram Solanki, come on down.

In the end, rain saved the day for England - whose one-day form so far has more in common with the cautious, creaking England of World Cup '99 than the risky, go-getting side who grabbed the Lord's Test by the scruff of the neck. Let's see some more sparkle at Old Trafford on Thursday - England's first-ever domestic ODI under lights.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Made in Britain?
fields.trailText: More of France's 22 newly-crowned European Champions can be found in England than any other country. But why?
fields.body:
More of France's 22 newly-crowned European Champions can be found in England than any other country. At the moment there are three times as many in the Premiership as there are in the French First Division. These are players whose reputations are soaring by the trophy, so coveted they could virtually handpick their club while Europe's giants woo them with their Blankety Blank cheque-books and pens. So why England?

Why Fabien Barthez, when you love to pose in Monte Carlo, do you jack it in for a place with a ridiculous amount of rain? Why Robert Pires have you rejected the Champions League holders for a club that under-achieves in Europe? Why Christian Karembeu have you traded Madrid for a town where, according to one of L'Equipe's most esteemed scribes, a French footballer would want to commit suicide after two weeks?

Reasons why the French come to England part one: The global package. This is what enticed Barthez. He knows he is joining a club with ambitions as vast as his own. Manchester United are, of course, in Europe, they boast a strong squad led by a clever coach, play in an exciting championship, and can afford to keep him in the manner to which he has become accustomed. Top French players who cross the Channel for anything other than money find it difficult to see beyond London or Old Trafford and while the capital gets the nod for lifestyle, Manchester wins for footballing status. In Monaco, in front of meagre crowds in their tiny jewel of a stadium, Barthez got bored. He responds to pressure, crowds and the hottest of spotlights. A born showman, he may well get the Mancunians singing a post-Eric reprise of The Marseillaise.

Reasons why the French come to England part two: Money. It is this that has lured Karembeu. It is optimistic to imagine an urbane sophisticate with cosmopolitan tastes, dreadlocked cool, a supermodel wife, an international double and a pair of Champions League winners medals living happily ever after on Teesside. But like Marcel Desailly, who doesn't seem overly enamoured by English football, the pull of the purse is too tempting. The Chelsea defender seemed eager to move at the end of last season but has stayed for an improved contract.

Reasons why the French come to England part three: Le Boss. Following in the footsteps of Patrick Vieira, Gilles Grimandi, Reme Garde, Nicolas Anelka, Emmanuel Petit and Thierry Henry, Pires has signed not only for Arsenal, but more importantly, for Arsène. After a season of despair at Marseille Pires needs a fresh challenge to develop a potential not yet fully realised. The burning question is whether he has the character to take that challenge on and answer those critics who say he's too nice, too fragile.

Ten years ago the dainty Pires would never have come to England. But the example of his predecessors gives him a decent chance. If David Ginola, hardly known for his toughness, could make such an impression on English football, why should he be afraid? French Anglophiles owe a debt to the trendsetters, Cantona and Ginola, who proved to Gallic sceptics that it was possible for artists to thrive among the hurly burly of les rosbifs .

The Frenchification of the Premiership looks set to continue. Two more looking to enhance their reputations here are Olivier Dacourt, who should profit more among the bright young things at Elland Road than he did during his spell with Everton, and Frederic Kanoute, of whom great things are expected at West Ham after his impressive loan period last season.

For your average French footballer, aside from the attractive combination of colossal wages, a cracking league and a cushy life there is less fear of failure in England than elsewhere. Significantly, Desailly believes the Premiership is an easier competition than Serie A, and it has not gone unnoticed that fewer Frenchmen flop in England than in Italy. Vieira and Henry are frequently used as examples of players who floundered in Serie A (at Milan and Juventus respectively), yet have flourished so fantastically in the Premiership the Italians would break the bank to have them back. So far, they seem happy to stay but you can't help feeling that they will some day find a second crack at the Southern European heavyweights irresistible.

This summer Serie A has taken on two new additions from France's Euro 2000 squad: Johan Micoud has gone to Parma and David Trezeguet to Juventus. You can bet your bottom franc that if they are not instant hits then by this time next year they will be in England.

Manchester United are, of course, in Europe, they boast a strong squad led by a clever coach, play in an exciting championship, and can afford to keep him in the manner to which he has become accustomed. Top French players who cross the Channel for anything other than money find it difficult to see beyond London or Old Trafford and while the capital gets the nod for lifestyle, Manchester wins for footballing status. In Monaco, in front of meagre crowds in their tiny jewel of a stadium, Barthez got bored. He responds to pressure, crowds and the hottest of spotlights. A born showman, he may well get the Mancunians singing a post-Eric reprise of The Marseillaise. Reasons why the French come to England part two: Money. It is this that has lured Karembeu. It is optimistic to imagine an urbane sophisticate with cosmopolitan tastes, dreadlocked cool, a supermodel wife, an international double and a pair of Champions League winners medals living happily ever after on Teesside. But like Marcel Desailly, who doesn't seem overly enamoured by English football, the pull of the purse is too tempting. The Chelsea defender seemed eager to move at the end of last season but has stayed for an improved contract. Reasons why the French come to England part three: Le Boss. Following in the footsteps of Patrick Vieira, Gilles Grimandi, Reme Garde, Nicolas Anelka, Emmanuel Petit and Thierry Henry, Pires has signed not only for Arsenal, but more importantly, for Arsène. After a season of despair at Marseille Pires needs a fresh challenge to develop a potential not yet fully realised. The burning question is whether he has the character to take that challenge on and answer those critics who say he's too nice, too fragile. Ten years ago the dainty Pires would never have come to England. But the example of his predecessors gives him a decent chance. If David Ginola, hardly known for his toughness, could make such an impression on English football, why should he be afraid? French Anglophiles owe a debt to the trendsetters, Cantona and Ginola, who proved to Gallic sceptics that it was possible for artists to thrive among the hurly burly of les rosbifs . The Frenchification of the Premiership looks set to continue. Two more looking to enhance their reputations here are Olivier Dacourt, who should profit more among the bright young things at Elland Road than he did during his spell with Everton, and Frederic Kanoute, of whom great things are expected at West Ham after his impressive loan period last season. For your average French footballer, aside from the attractive combination of colossal wages, a cracking league and a cushy life there is less fear of failure in England than elsewhere. Significantly, Desailly believes the Premiership is an easier competition than Serie A, and it has not gone unnoticed that fewer Frenchmen flop in England than in Italy. Vieira and Henry are frequently used as examples of players who floundered in Serie A (at Milan and Juventus respectively), yet have flourished so fantastically in the Premiership the Italians would break the bank to have them back. So far, they seem happy to stay but you can't help feeling that they will some day find a second crack at the Southern European heavyweights irresistible. This summer Serie A has taken on two new additions from France's Euro 2000 squad: Johan Micoud has gone to Parma and David Trezeguet to Juventus. You can bet your bottom franc that if they are not instant hits then by this time next year they will be in England.

webTitle: Lost in the jungle without a map...

fields.headline: Lost in the jungle without a map...
fields.standfirst: Kathryn Whitfield decides it is better to travel backwards to the prehistoric sites of Napoleon's island, whether on horseback or behind the wheel
fields.trailText: Kathryn Whitfield decides it is better to travel backwards to the prehistoric sites of Napoleon's island, whether on horseback or behind the wheel.
fields.body:
Sea, then sun, then sand: the view as my horse and I became separated. The horse moving in a downward direction and me sent skywards in a forward somersault.

Sand. The soft landing was harder than I thought. Peeling myself off the beach, I wondered about the wisdom of the riding school owner, Cathie - a fortysomething Bardot-esque blonde with aubergine jodhpurs and bosoms that could prove troublesome at a trot - who had matched myself, 'professional' rider (amateur was the only other category), and Prune, the horse that trips a lot.

There were only four of us on the half-day trek: Arlette (a nervous beginner), myself, my partner Vicente and our guide, Stéphane, who looked like a bronzed Peter Fonda with a pony-tail (yeah, it is spooky how everyone in Corsica looks like a movie star).

Partial to riding forward while facing backwards, Stéphane led us out from the stables, across a tiny airfield and along a spectacular sandy beach, the so-blue sea patting gently at the shore, not an umbrella in sight and only a few human-shaped shadows shimmering in the distant heat.

It was here that Prune fell and I flew. After checking that the bones of both rider and mount were where they ought to be, we headed uphill and into the dense jungle of maquis, the fragrant bushes that choke the island.

The horses were working harder now and even Prune had become sure-footed as we rode up higher, scrambling over rocks, scratched by the maquis and bitten by the sun. Stéphane, still facing backwards, signalled when to duck for dangerously low branches. (Alas, Arlette was not very flexible.)

After almost two hours (including injury time) we reached the lost village. For the first time since arriving in Corsica I was sure where I was.

We had started badly: after driving for more than an hour round Propriano, a small port, we still hadn't found the apartment. Then we spotted another rental car doing circles.

Mark and Sarah were looking for the same block and had been told, helpfully, that it had a white gate. We decided to join forces, stopping locals to ask for directions. Of course, no one knew where it was. Here the streets have no signposts, the apartment blocks no names. Finding a 'tourist attraction' is a challenge; even getting to the beach is difficult.

The southern tip of the island has not yet discovered tourism but, thankfully, it has spawned tour reps, one of whom finally led us, tired and hungry, to the pearly gates.

It doesn't help to have a guide book. I was armed with the Rough Guide and Lonely Planet but still managed to miss my target every time. They both suggested: 'to get to the Alignement de Pagliajo (with 258 menhirs - megalithic statues - it's the largest collection of its kind in the Mediterranean) park your car at the wine-tasting warehouse, then follow a dirt track behind it for about 1km'. We had wandered about 300m down a dirt track (there were several) when a man in a four-wheel-drive kindly pointed out that we were going the wrong way.

We got back in the car and drove about another kilometre down the main road to find a gate (as promised) on our right with a small sign saying: 'Menhirs. Please keep the gate closed.'

It was another two kilometres on foot to the site. I had been expecting a spectacular prehistoric version of China's rows of terracotta warriors, but was greeted by about 30 tombstone-like menhirs, jammed upright in scattered rows of six or so. I don't know what had become of the other 228. Perhaps they had been swallowed whole by the creeping, omnipresent maquis - or maybe someone had just left the gate open.

Not far away is Cauria, which has two alignements and a dolmen (stone burial site). The small sign marking the turn-off can be seen only if you are travelling the wrong way; you then follow the road until, as one guidebook instructs, you reach a sign riddled with bullet holes.

Another two-kilometre hike from there and you come across the Alignement de Stantari: a single row of nine standing menhirs, one of which has a sword carved into its chest and another with a face frozen in a scream. On the other side of this menhir, you can see the sculpted back of his head, shoulder blades and a spine.

Across yet another field, over and under several fences, is the Alignement de Renaggiu, an anarchic arrangement of stones and menhirs, some of which seem to form a path leading into a small wood, thought to have been sacred.

I was halfway up a cork tree, trying to negotiate the steps straddling another fence on my way to the burial site, when I realised just how clever our Sartenais cousins were. Not only had they carved and carted these stones here, around 2,500 years ago, using the most primitive of equipment, but they had a real purpose. They had chosen these sites for safety and the statues - thought to represent gods, the dead or even enemies - stood guard over them. So successful were they that even today they stand largely undisturbed, with only the most persistent travellers finding them.

The island's most famous prehistoric site, Filitosa, about an hour's drive north of Propriano, is in the middle of a town. There are lavatories, bars and souvenirs and postcards. You buy a ticket (and a guide book, whether you want it or not) to get in.

Here are the kings of menhirs: some tall, square and well-armed, some small with pointy noses and chiselled chins. They have been rearranged by their minders: no explanation is given, although the tourists who queue up to be photographed hugging one don't seem to mind.

But I missed the challenge. The feeling of breaking through the maquis to discover something special, mysterious.

The horses knew the way to the lost Genoese village well. Stéphane had made the place his own and led us from house to house, telling us the story of the stone shells that still stood.

Above the door of a wealthy man's house, the date 1719 was etched in stone; inside there were surprisingly good wash-basins built into a wall. There was a church, several small huts and a tower which still looked out to sea for enemy boats that had turned to dust long ago.

He told us how he had come to Corsica from mainland France on holiday, but 'couldn't get it out of his head'. He had subsequently travelled around the island four times. It doesn't surprise me: he was probably lost.

Corsica facts

Kathryn Whitfield travelled with Corsican Places in mid-season, flying from Stansted airport with European Air and staying in a self-catering apartment at the Residence Dominica, Propriano. The holiday includes a hire car and costs £598pp for one week, based on two people sharing.

Half-day riding trek along the beach and to the lost village with Les Ecuries de Tavaria, Route de Campomoro, Propriano (061 309 2510): Fr250 per person. Filitosa: Fr22 per person and about Fr30 for the (compulsory) guide book.

fields.headline: Health check
fields.trailText: Malaria.
fields.body:
So far this year, more than 3,300 cases of malaria have been reported in Goa in India. Of these, 818 have been the malignant form, falciparum, which can be fatal if early treatment is not sought. A large migrant labour force and rapid urbanisation have contributed to the spread of the disease in the area. Travellers are reminded that mosquito-bite avoidance measures and anti-malarials are advised for stays in this popular holiday destination. A combination of weekly chloroquine and daily proguanil is recommended but alternatives are available for those unable to take this regimen. If a fever develops for seven days or more and up to a year after being in a malarious area, prompt medical attention should be sought.

To obtain a health brief tailored to your journey call the MASTA Travellers Health Line on 09068 224100 (calls charged at 60p/min). For general travel health advice visit the website at www.masta.org.

fields.headline: Good morning, Trabolganners!
fields.standfirst: Maxine Jones treats her children to the authentic Irish Pontins holiday on the lovely coast of Co Cork
fields.trailText: Maxine Jones treats her children to the authentic Irish Pontins holiday on the lovely coast of Co Cork.
fields.body:
As an Englishwoman living in Ireland, two things marked me out as a non-native: I had visited neither New York nor Trabolgan. New York still awaits, but one frosty April weekend I set off with three expectant young sons for Trabolgan holiday village, in Co Cork.

The notion of a holiday camp does not sit easily with my impression of Irish people's spontaneity. The words conjured up a tormented country and western weekend I once spent in Prestatyn, North Wales. I can still smell the chip fat and the smelly lavatories.

Such a scenario seemed alien at Trabolgan, which is in a wooded valley with hills rising on either side and nothing ahead but the sea. Hidden among the trees were detached three-bedroom, two-bathroom houses, with dishwashers and microwaves.

A short walk away along wooded paths is its hub, a square with a pub, a fast food cafe, a restaurant, a concert hall, a shop and, filling one side and looking out across the Atlantic, a sub-tropical swimming pool. It was this, with its water slide and wave machine, that kept my children happiest, though the computer consoles in the cafe came a close second.

Holidays are for a week, four nights mid-week, or weekends. For the shorter stays there is a policy of not letting you into your house till 5pm and ordering you out at 10am on departure day. This seems a bit harsh, even taking into account that full-size houses have to be cleaned. Service in the restaurant can be slow, but these are minor carps.

The staff are friendly and helpful. Many are English and their tracksuits are emblazoned with the Pontins motif, but they are the first to point out that Trabolgan couldn't be further away from the average Pontins. 'Much quieter,' was the general opinion. The owner, Scottish and Newcastle Breweries, has put Pontins on the market but is selling Trabolgan separately.

The atmosphere is pleasant and easygoing. Few foreigners know of the place. Amazingly, in our three days,I don't think I heard one child cry. Reser vation systems for quad-bikes, abseiling, archery and aeroball (a cross between trampolining and basketball) avoid any queueing. Although the camp was full, the pool and playgrounds were never crowded, and the clifftop golf course was deserted.

The camp is set in 140 acres and has its own private cove, so it is easy to strike out alone. On the cliffs covered with bright yellow gorse and springy grass I didn't meet a soul, and stood captivated by a shoreline which stretched to the East without any sign of human habitation. Lungfuls of fresh air revitalised my system like a shot of whiskey.

For those who prefer the real thing, there are tours of the Old Midleton Distillery, home of Jameson's. At the end of the tour you are faced with several whiskey samples to identify.We poured out more garrulous than we went in.

Back at the camp, evening brought cabaret acts - the Nolan Sisters, Bucks Fizz and a couple of Stars in your Eyes imitators. I preferred to linger over dinner, while the children flitted between the cartoon cinema, indoor 'adventure land' and the computer consoles.

I rashly signed up for abseiling the next day. 'Look at me,' the instructor said. 'Don't look down.' I glanced at the sickening drop. Nausea gripped my stomach and the blood drained from my legs. I looked at him. In the intensity of the moment every pore and pimple of his face was imprinted on my mind. He wanted me to inch my heels over the edge of the wooden platform, and fall backwards into space. I didn't think I'd bottle out, but I did. I climbed back down the ladders feeling no shame, only intense relief. The chil dren, off playing crazy golf, had not seen me.

I was a regular visitor to the sauna, where a retired garda told me about the eighteenth-century Trabolgan mansion and its army of servants. In the Forties, chalets were built for tourists fleeing food shortages in Britain - ironic in the land of the potato famine. The swimming pool now occupies the site of the mansion. I asked local people about the origins of the name Trabolgan. My favourite, even if it is not strictly accurate, was 'beach of the big belly'.

Fact file

Renting a house at Trabolgan costs from IR£275 (£210) a week and IR£190 (£145) for a mid-week or weekend stay. The resort has a caravan park for 35 vans. The weekly rates for these pitches start at IR£120 per week (about £92). Book direct with Trabolgan, on 00 353 21 4 661 551, and arrange your own flight or ferry. (The fare on the Swansea-Cork sea route is £139 return for a car and five passengers) or both ferry and accommodation can be booked through Pontins, in the UK, on 0870 604 5621, or with Stena Line (0870 574 7474), Irish Ferries (0990 170000) or Hoseasons (01502 500 500).

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Hiking for lava lovers | Ice and a slice of danger | Secrets of the wild
fields.body:
Hiking for lava lovers

Mount Etna in Sicily continues to be active, which will suit those thrill seekers who want to be at the centre of the action. Explore Worldwide have organised a number of volcano hikes to the edge of the action, if not the centre of it. You can travel from Heathrow or join the seven-night tour in Catania for some moderate to strenuous hiking. Travellers climb Vulcano on the second day to sample the volcanic gases and the healthier mudbaths at the base. The ascent of the second volcano, Stromboli, is timed so that climbers reach the top at sundown when the flying sparks and incandescent lava appear at their most dramatic. The culmination of the trip is a day-long walk to the summit craters of Mount Etna. Accommodation is in local hotels and transport between the volcanic islands is by ferry. Prices start at £699 including flights. Phone 01252 760000.

Ice and a slice of danger

The ice tinkling gently in martini glasses is usually the only kind to be found on most cruises, but bigger lumps can be found in Peregrine Adventures' new Antarctica and Islands of the South Atlantic brochure. It features a number of trips on the Peregrine Mariner, a refurbished Russian research vessel specially equipped for ice cruises such as the nine-night Antarctic Encounter, which departs from Ushuaia, Argentina and goes on to the South Shetlands before returning on a route that takes in Cape Horn. This is not for the faint-hearted: a night camping on the ice is offered, as are shore excursions by inflatable boat to examine the sights and wildlife at close quarters. The expert crew offer a full programme of lectures. This cruise starts at £2,556 including transfers and meals, but not international flights. Phone 020 8772 3700.

Secrets of the wild

Travellers bewildered by the wilderness could benefit from a new holiday idea from Discovery Initiatives. A course in South Africa led by a game ranger and guide aims to impart the secrets of the wild to anyone who wants to experience bush life. Far from being just a sightseeing holiday, the 11-day trip focuses on conservation skills but casual visitors should beware as there is a written test at the end of the course. The holiday is based in a safari bushcamp for several nights, but novices can put their skills to use by sleeping out in the bush or around the campfire, identifying the nocturnal wildlife noises. The starting price is £1,125 excluding international flights. Phone 020 7924 5696.

It features a number of trips on the Peregrine Mariner, a refurbished Russian research vessel specially equipped for ice cruises such as the nine-night Antarctic Encounter, which departs from Ushuaia, Argentina and goes on to the South Shetlands before returning on a route that takes in Cape Horn. The expert crew offer a full programme of lectures. This cruise starts at £2,556 including transfers and meals, but not international flights. Phone 020 8772 3700. Secrets of the wild Travellers bewildered by the wilderness could benefit from a new holiday idea from Discovery Initiatives. The holiday is based in a safari bushcamp for several nights, but novices can put their skills to use by sleeping out in the bush or around the campfire, identifying the nocturnal wildlife noises. The starting price is £1,125 excluding international flights. Phone 020 7924 5696.

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Ten things to do today.
fields.body:
 Find out why your favourite jumper shrank in the wash, how trends go from catwalk to high street and why people go to the trouble of adornment in the first place at Fashion Works, Discovery Museum, Newcastle upon Tyne. 2pm-5pm. Free. Call 0191 232 6789.

 Enjoy an eclectic summer music festival in Calder Holmes Park, Hebden Bridge, Yorkshire. The programme includes cajun, jazz, blues and a concert pianist - and, as the acts change every 20 or 40 minutes, no one has to wait long for their favourite. Noon- 8pm. Free. Call 07720 884372.

 Nearly 50 playbuses will converge on Hengrove Park, Bristol, to take part in the Big Bus Bash. Children will be able to throw themselves into paint spinning, drama and circus workshops, costume making and more than 200 other activities in the company of the buses' playleaders. 9.30am-5.30pm. Free.

 A corner of Surrey becomes Little Italy today as Brooklands Museum, Weybridge, holds an Italian Festival, with an Italian food fair and wine tasting. Big and little children will love the display of 800 Italian cars from Ferrari to Fiat. 10am-5pm. Adults £7, children £5. Call 01932 857381.

 The Three Musketeers come to Heigham Park, Norwich, as part of the city's Theatre in the Parks Festival. The performance draws on puppetry, live music and audience participation - you have been warned. 4pm. Free.

 The Greenwich and Docklands International Festival in London ends tonight with the opening of the Arsenal Gardens, Woolwich. An aerial acrobatics troupe with a fondness for Seventies costumes and disco music and a massive fireworks display will mark the event. 8.30pm. Free.

 A doorbell made from wine glasses and a self-lighting lampshade were two of the innovations inflicted on Glaswegian householders by Droog Design. Find out from their video diaries how they got on with the wacky designs as well as trying them out yourself in a household setting at The Lighthouse, Mitchell Lane, Glasgow. Noon-5pm. £1.Call 0141 225 8414.

 Help make a contribution to safety at sea without getting your feet wet at The Blessing of the Boats, Harbourside, Whitby, Yorkshire. The Bishop of Whitby blesses the fishing fleet and pleasure craft in this popular old custom from 2.30pm. Free. Call 01947 602674.

 Stilt walkers, storytellers, magicians and puppeteers will be helping to make the grand finale of Children's Festival 2000 at the Museum of Welsh Life, Cardiff. The packed and varied programme runs from 10am-5pm. Adults £5.50, children free. Call 02920 573500.

 Find out why diets in Victorian times - before the microwave and the freezer - were much healthier than today's as recipes, secrets and ingredients from the nineteenth century are explained by a fully costumed chef as part of the Eat, Drink and Be Merry exhibition at Kenwood House, Hampstead Lane, London. 10am-6pm. Adults £3.50, children £1. Call 020 8348 1286.

fields.headline: At your service
fields.standfirst: A top concierge reveals all
fields.trailText: A top concierge reveals all
fields.body:
The Savoy, London

Paul Pugh, head concierge

Any famous guests?

A lot people pass through the hotel, if only to eat or drink. We have an opera singer here at the moment and I've seen two previous Prime Ministers in the past week.

Any unusual requests?

We have a very high-spirited American lady staying with us and by the end of the day she wants me to have arranged for her to run in the Pamplona bull-running event. Another guest recently wanted to take a private jet to Sardinia on a whim, so we had to put that together in a couple of hours. Last week a lady requested a bullet-proof evening gown for a function. You have to have a sense of humour in this industry, and we all share the best stories. With the right contacts you can do anything. A very demanding guest has been with us for a week and he comes up with a challenge every day. Today he wanted to know if it was raining at Wimbledon, but he didn't trust the forecasters. I went to the Wimbledon internet site on my computer and showed him the view from the webcam, raindrops and all.

So the Savoy is moving with the times?

Yes, the technology available today means that information is much more accessible, although many people in the industry haven't had much exposure to technology.

The Savoy is a bit of an institution. Last week a gentleman came up to my desk and told me that he had visited the hotel in 1938 for a theatre trip, and had left his car in the garage. I was a bit confused, until he said that he hadn't paid for it at the time and tried to give me £20 to cover the charge. I declined the money and he gave it to charity.

What about a day out?

The Season, which begins with the Chelsea Flower Show and continues through Royal Ascot, Wimbledon and Henley is our busiest time of year. The Savoy Rolls-Royce is hired out all the time.

Royal Ascot is a great day out. It's an opportunity to really dress up: people go to be seen rather than gamble. London's South Bank has been totally redeveloped and there are lots of attractions such as the Eye, the Globe Theatre, Tate Modern and Vinopolis - which is outstanding. The city is a melting pot of restaurants, if people still have the energy to go out. The Ivy is still the most popular, but Oliver Peyton's new opening, The Admiralty, looks good.

The Savoy: 020 7836 4343

The Admiralty: 020 7845 4646

Vinopolis: 020 7645 3700

fields.headline: On Eden's shore...
fields.standfirst: Tim Adams in the Seychelles visits the two finest beaches in the world and meets a modern Robinson Crusoe - and his wife
fields.trailText: We all think we can imagine a perfect beach. But what is it that makes one strip of palm-shaded ocean-scoured sand better than any other?
fields.body:
We all think we can imagine a perfect beach. But what is it that makes one strip of palm-shaded ocean-scoured sand better than any other?

Many of the beaches of the Seychelles come pre-packaged with unique selling points: this, you discover, is the Bounty Bar Beach and that, a lone palm tree stretching out nearly horizontal to the ocean, is the Bacardi Beach. On your right, a guide informs you matter-of-factly, pointing toward a slim crevice in the cliff, is 'Robinson Crusoe's cave', while 'in front of you The Blue Lagoon was filmed with Miss Brooke Shields'; a little further on, you arrive at 'the location for Emmanuelle with Miss Sylvia Kristel'.

But there are a couple of stretches of sand on the islands which purport to go one better even than these eclectic celluloid fantasies. Up in the north-west corner of Praslin, the second largest of the Seychelles main group of islands, are what, by some accounts, are the two finest beaches in the world. Who says so? Well, some German tourists, of course, who got here first and who had a notion that things like perfection are best quantified.

Still, when a Berlin-based travel magazine invited its readers to nominate their favourite places on Earth to pitch towels, in first place they ranked Anse Lazio on the northern tip of Praslin and in second place they nominated Anse Georgette a mile to the south. Spend a day on either and, while acknowledging that both would be hard to beat, you come to realise that a beach hit parade is a subjective business.

Despite their proximity, the two beaches could hardly be more different: Anse Lazio boasted a car park full of four-wheel drives and a large restaurant and was relatively dense with afternoon bathers; Anse Georgette was accessible only by boat, or by strong swimmers, or overland through a stretch of jungle in the torpid heat, and was deserted.

In a vague attempt to bring some science to the question, I sat in the circle of shade cast by the ancient and low slung takamaka tree that provides a landmark at the back of Anse Lazio, and lay subsequently in the afternoon sun on Anse Georgette, and squinted half-heartedly at a recently published doorstop tome on the idea of The Beach , written by American academics Lena Lencek and Gideon Bosker (and not to be confused with Alex Garland's somewhat better selling book of the same name), which promised to offer a detailed biography of paradise.

In the rather exhaustive view of Lencek and Bosker - and their treatise took into detailed account 'the discreet charms of the bourgeois beach' and the particular pleasures of the 'blue-chip beach', the 'erotic beach' and the 'edifying beach' - the ideal Anse, it seems, 'collapses past and present into a matrix of water, sand, space and light, and moves us with the power of a drug, reorienting our sense of time and firing our slumbering hedonism'. After some (reoriented) hours of research, and the odd invigorating entanglement in the matrix of water and light (dips in the sea) I decided that both beaches succeeded on all counts (though if pressed I'd probably have my ashes scattered on Georgette).

For all their beauty, though - and their firing of slumbering hedonism - beaches are not wholly the point of a holiday in the Seychelles. In many ways they should be seen simply as spectacular arrivals and departures lounges as you tour the islands by boat.

The Seychelles are made for tropical Swallows and Amazoning, and Praslin, centrally located and accessible by air from the main island, Mahe, makes the perfect base: a little less busier than Mahe (Prasliners refer to Victoria, the world's tiniest capital, with shakes of their head, as if it was south-central Los Angeles) it none the less boasts some great places to stay, none better than the newly opened and spectacular Lemuria Resort, with its new championship golf course hanging over the sea and where, for example, if you play tennis, you may well be offered champagne, between points.

In just under a week we visited half a dozen different islands from Praslin: some, like Coco Island, only smooth grey protrusions from the sea that provided anchorage for snorkelling - which including the thrill of swimming above a sea turtle as it made its thoughtful way between rocks, eyes blinking studiously; others big enough to have cemented their own particular culture: cars are banned, for example, from La Digue (a favourite destination of the Blairs), and we toured the island south to north raindrops-keep-falling-on-my-head style on boneshaking bikes (ox carts are the alternative, more sedate option).

As well as its own atmosphere, each of the islands boasts its own flora and fauna. On Praslin, most spectacularly, the extraordinary coco-de-mer plants grow in the island's protected central rainforest, the Vallée de Mai: vast trees that produce phallic catkins and wonderful buttock-shaped nuts, and which 'mate' (there are males and females) only on stormy nights, or by the light of the full moon, or when they are in the mood, depending on which myth you want to believe. (General Gordon of Khartoum was so entranced by this place that he declared it the original site of the Garden of Eden and the coco-de-mer the tree of life; his belief is given slightly more weight by the fact that, oddly, and despite many efforts over the centuries, the trees will propagate nowhere else on earth). On Curieuse, a half-hour boat trip to the north, we walked among the famed giant tortoises - 250 live and breed here and roam freely - which tore slowly at grass and occasionally rose on their haunches and mooched past each other, apparently frustrated with the paparazzi; while on Aride, further north again, half a million seabirds wheeled around the sheer granite cliffs, overseen by frigate birds, with their enormous wingspans, hovering.

Apart from its its teeming bird population Aride is home to a nesting pair of British ornithologists, happily named Janet and John, who have lived here as virtual Crusoes for a couple of years with a small team of local volunteers. The group live in a makeshift compound of huts near the water's edge, by day studying the birds and turning out en masse to help the odd tourist boat through the heavy surf; by night attempting to protect the birds' nesting sites from poachers, who have, in the past, been known to make off with as many as a 1,000 eggs in one landing. The poachers can be fairly ruthless, Janet explained, and the islanders are armed only with 'torches and polite persuasion', but still this year the numbers of thefts has decreased.

The group do a great little tour of the island, too: ours was conducted by Jimmy, a rasta twitcher, who led us animatedly through the forest collecting spices - ginger, saffron, aniseed - and carefully uncovering the ground-level nests of Noddy terns (there are no cats or rats on Aride to disturb them), pointing out flitting red-tailed tropic birds or letting Sooty terns perch on his shoulders, a dreadlocked Dr Dolittle. Jimmy, a native of Praslin, has lived here for a couple of years, and rarely ventured back to the bigger islands. He explained, smiling broadly, that the only thing he really missed were 'women, I guess'; Janet and John meanwhile, who joined us for a beach picnic, their eyes lighting up at the sight of strawberries, confessed to craving chocolate the most - somewhat ironically since the island is owned and protected by the Cadbury family. James Cadbury is an annual visitor, but even his rations, it seems, are quickly consumed.

Over lunch John explained how they came to be here: they were selected Castaway -style from dozens of other applicants, on their perceived ability to survive together alone; John had spent the previous nine years studying swans bottoms for a Phd: his theory - which proved that the larger the bottom the more successful the female - was one of the few works of doctoral biology to have aroused the interest of the Sun .

John's theory seemed to hold true, too, in Praslin's main nightspot, Bufe (the cupboard), into which entire younger portion of the island's 6,000 inhabitants squeezed every Friday and Saturday night; hemp is dried on the beach nearby, so it was a mellow crowd that seemed suitably unfazed by the DJ's odd predilection for Shakin' Stevens. Bufe is just down the road from Praslin's newly built colonial-style casino: a good place to unburden yourself of troublesome Seychellois rupees, before watching seasoned locals clean-up on the blackjack tables.

The tourist brochures describe the Seychelles as 'unique by a thousand miles' and certainly moving between the islands you have a sense of being adrift from the rest of the world; there are no major diseases here, few mosquitoes, little apparent poverty - the islands enjoy the highest standard of living of any 'developing country' - and fairly relaxed mores: Praslin men, for example, frequently have children with four or five local concubinos.

Certainly, lying on Anse Georgette, past and present suitably compressed, you could half convince yourself that General Gordon was right all along; or perhaps it is just that 'matrix of water, sand, space and light' doing its particular stuff.

Getting there

Tim Adams stayed on Praslin at the five-star Lemuria Resort which can be booked through Classic Connection which offers tailormade itineraries to the Indian Ocean.

Lemuria Resort is the newest luxury five star property to open in the Seychelles. Prices for a seven night stay in a Junior Suite on a bed & breakfast basis start at £1694 per person, rising to £3086 per person in high season. Prices include return economy flights with Air Seychelles and private transfers.

Classic Connection also has a Caribbean, African and Worldwide portfolio.

webTitle: The right way to do the Palio

fields.headline: The right way to do the Palio
fields.standfirst: Avoid the crush at Siena's big race and you'll see more, says  Sarah Ryle
fields.trailText: Avoid the crush at Siena's big race and you'll see more, says Sarah Ryle.
fields.body:
So you missed last Sunday's Siena Palio and, unlike Tony Blair and his family who will be Tuscan guests once more this year, you are unlikely to secure a ringside seat in the Piazza del Campo for the next race on 16 August.

Excellent: the alternative Palio is more fun. Those who opt to roam the streets of Siena for the build-up and watch the race on TV in a cafe with a mass of hysterical humanity have got it right. To those who rejected the prospect of sweating it out with a 40,000-strong crowd in the Campo comes the glory of joining the post-race party at the Duomo while the supposedly lucky ones remain trapped in the piazza until the police let them out.

Do it the ligger's way. Do not stay in the city itself unless you do not mind paying premiums for what few hotel rooms are left. Catch the first train in, or park your hired car in one of the 24-hour multi-storeys.

Watch the warm-up race on the soft, orange earth at 9am when the Campo is virtually empty. Drink strong coffee and eat panini for breakfast in one of the jam-packed cafes already abuzz - but at that time of day with Italians not Americans, Germans or Japanese.

See the sights early. The Pinacoteca is famous, so is the Palazzo Pubblico and its Lego-look tower. But you won't get round everything in a day, so why torture yourself? Get out there and enjoy the atmosphere.

The streets are awash with colour. Every building displays its contrada's (district's) flag, so find a church and watch a horse blessing: 'Go, little horse, and return victorious.' Follow the procession of flag-waving men in medieval costume. Women trot along chanting the Palio song, with words tailored to district rivalries: 'You revolt the city', and 'We are an electric current, touch us and you die'.

Drums drive the euphoric crowd closer to the altar. Weeping skinheads and unshirted old men clasp each other. Chubby women are helped up to teetering vantage points on antique pews by teenage daughters.

Afterwards it is off to the ancient streets in the winner's territory to celebrate. Don't stay till the end - the party lasts for weeks.

fields.headline: Rain saves England at Lord's
fields.standfirst:
England 158 for 8 (43.5 overs)
Match abandoned
fields.trailText: The NatWest Triangular Series game between England and West Indies at Lord's was abandoned at 5pm after heavy rain had fallen for most of the afternoon. West Indies, who won the toss and elected to field in damp conditions, had restricted England to 158 for 8 after 43.5 overs. Marcus Trescothick followed his debut 79 yesterday against Zimbabwe with a cleanly struck 49, but received little support as the innings fell away dismally. Both sides take one point, and still trail Zimbabwe by three.
fields.body:
The NatWest Triangular Series game between England and West Indies at Lord's was abandoned at 5pm after heavy rain had fallen for most of the afternoon. West Indies, who won the toss and elected to field in damp conditions, had restricted England to 158 for 8 after 43.5 overs. Marcus Trescothick followed his debut 79 yesterday against Zimbabwe with a cleanly struck 49, but received little support as the innings fell away dismally. Both sides take one point, and still trail Zimbabwe by three.

Alec Stewart was first to go. He had looked in good nick early on, striking two boundaries in Corey Collymore's first over, but Nixon McLean tied him down, then had him edging to second slip for 12 to make it 23 for 1. Graeme Hick pulled Collymore and McLean for fours, but McLean got his revenge - and his second wicket - when he found Hick's inside edge with a ball that jagged back into him. Ridley Jacobs held the catch, Hick was out for 12, and England were 41 for 2.

When Matthew Maynard, bowled yesterday by a full-toss for 2, was castled by Collymore for 0 offering no stroke to complete a miserable return to international cricket, England were in real trouble at 47 for 3.

But Trescothick was playing fluently, and unleashed a glorious square-drive for four off Franklyn Rose, followed by another boundary through extra-cover in the same over. Four overs later Graham Thorpe cut Mervyn Dillon for four more, and the 50 partnership came up a ball later.

Then things started to go wrong. Trescothick gave part-time offspinner Chris Gayle a simple return catch to fall one short of a second successive fifty (99 for 4) and the runs dried up. Dillon was finding lift and bounce from the Pavilion end, while Thorpe and White showed a bizarre reluctance to use their feet to Gayle's innocuous dobbers.

White fell with the score on 120, caught behind off Dillon for 10 off 29 balls, and by the time Mark Ealham clubbed McLean for four through point in the 40th over, England had scored their first boundary for 15 overs. It was dull, dumb batting, and with steady rain falling, hardly a thriller for the spectators.

But it got even dumber. Thorpe lifted Rose straight to Dillon at mid-off for 42, an innings that never really got going, and in the next over Ealham was bowled by a straight one from Gayle as he tried to work the ball down to third man. Ealham was out for 17, and England were 152 for 7. More damningly, Gayle had been allowed to bowl ten overs for 28, with barely an attacking shot in sight. If England treat someone like him with respect, God help them this on the sub-continental turners this winter against Saqlain Mushtaq and Muttiah Muralitharan.

Andy Caddick lifted Rose straight to Gayle at midwicket in the next over for 0, and England were 153 for 8 with more than seven overs to come. But shortly after, with the rain getting heavier, the umpires decided enough was enough and took the players off. They returned for five balls an hour later, but the rain came back, and play was finally abandoned at 5pm. England breath again - for the moment.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com
