fields.headline: Recipes to help with depression
fields.standfirst: Jane Clarke on how food can help enhance your mood
fields.trailText: Jane Clarke on how food can help enhance your mood
fields.body:
Depression

Although it cannot cure depression, food can help enhance your mood. If you're feeling down, follow some of these guidelines.

 Make sure to eat lots of lean protein. It contains tryptophan and L-phenylalanine - substances that encourage the brain to produce the endorphins serotonin and noradrenaline (happy hormones).

 Monitor your intake of sugary foods. Although they may result in your brain producing short bursts of endorphins, the sugar swings that they cause usually trigger mood crashes.

 Try not to eat sugary foods until your stomach contains fibre-rich foods such as vegetables, pulses and wholegrains, as fibre suppresses rapid increases in your blood-sugar level and hence mood swings. Ensure that you eat plenty of fresh fruit (at least four pieces a day) because fruit contains slow-release sugars, which can lift and sustain your mood.

 Try to eat as much fresh produce as possible. It contains high levels of vitamins and minerals, the nutrients required to maintain a healthy body and mind.

 Drink enough water to help your body to absorb the beneficial nutrients in food. Adults should have 2 to 3 litres a day.

 Don't drink too many caffeine-containing drinks. Not only can caffeine adversely affect your mood and energy levels, it can also inhibit your body's absorption of the beneficial nutrients in food. Keep your intake to a maximum of three cups a day.

Cherries dipped in chocolate
serves 4
Magic ingredient cherries

The cherries will help your brain to produce the mood-enhancing hormones serotonin and noradrenaline. They also contain high levels of potassium, a mineral that helps prevent and correct high blood pressure.

20 firm ripe cherries with stems intact, 300g (10? oz) good-quality, plain eating chocolate, broken into small, even-sized pieces

Carefully wash and dry the cherries, making sure to leave the stems intact. Break the chocolate into a heatproof bowl that can sit on top of a saucepan. Pour boiling water into a saucepan, then place the heatproof bowl containing the chocolate pieces over the water, making sure that the bottom of the bowl does not come in contact with the water. Stir the chocolate as it melts to ensure a smooth and even consistency. Remove the bowl from the pan once the chocolate has melted. Holding a cherry by its stem, dip into the chocolate, submerging the fruit halfway. Allow the excess chocolate to drip off and place the cherry on baking parchment to set. Work quickly through all the cherries before the chocolate begins to solidify. Make sure that no water remains on the cherries before dipping.

Swings in blood sugar and energy levels

Swings in your blood-sugar and energy levels can seriously affect both your mood and performance. If you experience such swings, try taking the following measures. l Although it may be tempting to reach for foods that contain 'quick-fix' sugars, they will only make the problem worse.

 Chocolate and other sweet foods cause your blood-sugar level to rise quickly, which stimulates the pancreas to produce insulin, the hormone that rapidly brings it down.

 Fresh fruits give the best slow-release, energy boost, so increase your fruit intake.

 Eat plenty of protein-rich foods, including cheese, eggs, fish and chicken, especially for lunch, if you find that late afternoon is when your blood-sugar and energy levels crash. These foods will enable your body to control its blood-sugar levels more effectively.

 Eat lots of chromium-rich foods, such as cheese, shellfish, baked beans and wholemeal products. Chromium helps your body overcome symptoms of hypoglycaemia (low blood sugar).

 Make sure that you drink plenty of water throughout the day to enable all of the energising vitamins, minerals and slow-release sugars in the food that you eat to be absorbed by your body. Adults should aim to drink 2 to 3 litres of water a day.

 Only drink alcohol when your stomach is full. Because alcohol is absorbed so quickly it causes the blood-sugar level to drop. The presence of food in the stomach slows down the rate of absorption, thereby lessening blood-sugar swings.

 If you are a smoker, try to give up. Nicotine inhibits the body's production of insulin and glucagon, both hormones that maintain a constant blood-sugar level.

Poached fresh figs
serves 6
Magic ingredient figs

Figs contain fructose-fruit sugar, which in the presence of fibre (conveniently also found within the figs) gives our body a slow-release, sustainable energy burst. You may be surprised to find sugar within the juice, but the fig fibre ensures that the sugar is absorbed slowly.

600ml (1 pint) Italian red wine, 225g (8oz) white sugar, 18 fresh, ripe figs

Place the wine and sugar in a non-aluminium saucepan large enough to hold all of the figs in one layer. Warm over a medium heat until the sugar has dissolved. Holding the figs by their stems, drop them gently into the wine-and-sugar mixture. Lower to a gentle heat and simmer for 7 to 10 minutes, until the figs are tender and deep-brown in colour. Using a slotted spoon, remove the figs, being careful that they don't burst, and transfer them to a serving dish. Reduce the syrup for about 6 minutes, or until it has become thick. Pour the syrup over the figs and allow the dish to cool to room temperature.

webTitle: Recipes for a lunch and breakfast-time boost

fields.headline: Recipes for a lunch and breakfast-time boost
fields.standfirst: Jane Clarke makes some suggestions for improving on dreary breakfasts and lunches
fields.trailText: Jane Clarke makes some suggestions for improving on dreary breakfasts and lunches
fields.body:
Banana and pineapple energising fruit smoothie
makes 1 large glass Magic ingredient bananas

Bananas are full of slow-release sugars, so if you have one for breakfast - perhaps in this smoothie - it will sustain your energy levels throughout the rest of the morning. Note that this smoothie can't be kept for long, because after a while the banana will turn grey. In addition, don't keep the smoothie in the fridge, because this can cause the banana to change its chemical composition and thereby cause stomach upsets. It also causes the banana to turn an unappetising grey.

3 bananas, 1/2 fresh pineapple, skin and core removed, 3 tbsps natural yogurt

Purée all of the ingredients together in a liquidiser until smooth and then drink immediately.

Porridge with honey and apple purée
serves 1
Magic ingredient apples

Apples are rich in cholesterol-lowering fibre. Remember to drink some water or freshly squeezed fruit juice when eating porridge, in order to help your body deal efficiently with the nutrients and fibre that it contains. The size of the cup that you use to measure the ingredients doesn't matter, as long as you get the proportions of oats to water right.

Apple purée
2 large Bramley apples, peeled and cored, juice of ? lemon, dash of water

Porridge
1 cup porridge oats, 2 cups water or milk (or a mixture of the two), pinch of salt or brown sugar, 1 tbsp acacia or runny honey (optional)

Make the apple purée by slicing the apples into a small saucepan and adding the lemon juice and a dash of water. Bring to the boil, then cover and simmer for 10 minutes, or until the apples are soft, stirring occasionally. Using either a hand blender or a fork, mash the apple into a soft purée. (The purée can be kept covered in the fridge for a few days.) Place the oats, water or milk and salt or brown sugar in a saucepan and bring to the boil, stirring all the time. Simmer for 5-10 minutes (depending on desired texture), and continue stirring. Gently stir the apple purée (and a little honey, if you prefer a slightly sweeter taste) into the porridge and serve at once.

Long and short lunches

Asparagus and lemon salad
serves 2
Magic ingredient lemon

The lemon contained in the citron confit used in this salad is rich in vitamin C, which, like the folic acid in the asparagus, assists the body to absorb iron and other essential nutrients. Folic acid is particularly important during pregnancy and also plays a role in preventing iron-deficiency anaemia, as well as heart disease. The citron confit (lemon preserved in filtered water, fleur de Siel and herbs, available from specialist delicatessens) has a wonderfully concentrated flavour, which means that you only need to use a thin slither.

1 large bunch asparagus, washed and trimmed, 150g (5oz) fresh or frozen broad beans, 1 ripe avocado, 2 heads of chicory, washed and outside leaves removed, 1/8 citron confit, thinly sliced, or the juice of 1 lemon, dash of olive oil, salt and freshly ground black pepper

Steam the asparagus and broad beans until they are al dente. Plunge them into cold water immediately to cool them quickly and then drain well. When they are cool enough to handle, remove the skins from the broad beans to reveal their bright green hearts. Peel and stone the avocado, then cut it into thin slices. Separate the leaves from the chicory heads and arrange them on a serving plate with the beans, asparagus and avocado slices. Arrange the citron confit slices or sprinkle the lemon juice over the salad. Drizzle the salad with a little olive oil and lemon juice. Season the salad to taste and then toss it gently to ensure that the dressing is evenly distributed.

Focaccia with chargrilled peppers and ham
serves 4
Magic ingredient focaccia

The focaccia in this quick-to-make, satisfying sandwich contains olive oil, which in turn contains monounsaturated fats that boost the levels of the 'good' form of cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein (HDL), within the blood. High HDL levels can help ward off heart attacks, strokes and circulation problems. Starch within bread can make you feel a little sleepy after eating it, so by just having a slice of light focaccia, as opposed to two heavier slices of stodgy bread, you should feel satisfied, but not too sluggish.

crunchy grain mustard, 4 slices focaccia bread, 2 red or yellow peppers, sliced, 2 beef tomatoes, 4 slices lean, honey-roasted ham

Preheat the grill to a high heat. Lightly spread a little grain mustard over the focaccia slices. Place the peppers and tomatoes, skin-side uppermost, under the hot grill to brown or char. Leave them to cool. Divide the peppers and tomatoes between the four slices of focaccia and top with the ham.

(The purée can be kept covered in the fridge for a few days.) Place the oats, water or milk and salt or brown sugar in a saucepan and bring to the boil, stirring all the time. Simmer for 5-10 minutes (depending on desired texture), and continue stirring. Gently stir the apple purée (and a little honey, if you prefer a slightly sweeter taste) into the porridge and serve at once.

Long and short lunches

Asparagus and lemon salad
serves 2
Magic ingredient lemon

The lemon contained in the citron confit used in this salad is rich in vitamin C, which, like the folic acid in the asparagus, assists the body to absorb iron and other essential nutrients. Folic acid is particularly important during pregnancy and also plays a role in preventing iron-deficiency anaemia, as well as heart disease. The citron confit (lemon preserved in filtered water, fleur de Siel and herbs, available from specialist delicatessens) has a wonderfully concentrated flavour, which means that you only need to use a thin slither.

1 large bunch asparagus, washed and trimmed, 150g (5oz) fresh or frozen broad beans, 1 ripe avocado, 2 heads of chicory, washed and outside leaves removed, 1/8 citron confit, thinly sliced, or the juice of 1 lemon, dash of olive oil, salt and freshly ground black pepper

Steam the asparagus and broad beans until they are al dente. Plunge them into cold water immediately to cool them quickly and then drain well. When they are cool enough to handle, remove the skins from the broad beans to reveal their bright green hearts. Peel and stone the avocado, then cut it into thin slices. Separate the leaves from the chicory heads and arrange them on a serving plate with the beans, asparagus and avocado slices. Arrange the citron confit slices or sprinkle the lemon juice over the salad. Drizzle the salad with a little olive oil and lemon juice. Focaccia with chargrilled peppers and ham
serves 4
Magic ingredient focaccia

High HDL levels can help ward off heart attacks, strokes and circulation problems. crunchy grain mustard, 4 slices focaccia bread, 2 red or yellow peppers, sliced, 2 beef tomatoes, 4 slices lean, honey-roasted ham

Depression

Although it cannot cure depression, food can help enhance your mood. If you're feeling down, follow some of these guidelines.

 Make sure to eat lots of lean protein. It contains tryptophan and L-phenylalanine - substances that encourage the brain to produce the endorphins serotonin and noradrenaline (happy hormones).

 Monitor your intake of sugary foods. Although they may result in your brain producing short bursts of endorphins, the sugar swings that they cause usually trigger mood crashes.

 Try not to eat sugary foods until your stomach contains fibre-rich foods such as vegetables, pulses and wholegrains, as fibre suppresses rapid increases in your blood-sugar level and hence mood swings. Ensure that you eat plenty of fresh fruit (at least four pieces a day) because fruit contains slow-release sugars, which can lift and sustain your mood.

 Try to eat as much fresh produce as possible. It contains high levels of vitamins and minerals, the nutrients required to maintain a healthy body and mind.

 Drink enough water to help your body to absorb the beneficial nutrients in food. Adults should have 2 to 3 litres a day.

 Don't drink too many caffeine-containing drinks. Not only can caffeine adversely affect your mood and energy levels, it can also inhibit your body's absorption of the beneficial nutrients in food. Keep your intake to a maximum of three cups a day.

serves 4
Magic ingredient cherries

The cherries will help your brain to produce the mood-enhancing hormones serotonin and noradrenaline. They also contain high levels of potassium, a mineral that helps prevent and correct high blood pressure.

Pour boiling water into a saucepan, then place the heatproof bowl containing the chocolate pieces over the water, making sure that the bottom of the bowl does not come in contact with the water. Holding a cherry by its stem, dip into the chocolate, submerging the fruit halfway. Allow the excess chocolate to drip off and place the cherry on baking parchment to set. Work quickly through all the cherries before the chocolate begins to solidify. Make sure that no water remains on the cherries before dipping.

Swings in blood sugar and energy levels

Swings in your blood-sugar and energy levels can seriously affect both your mood and performance. If you experience such swings, try taking the following measures. l Although it may be tempting to reach for foods that contain 'quick-fix' sugars, they will only make the problem worse.

 Chocolate and other sweet foods cause your blood-sugar level to rise quickly, which stimulates the pancreas to produce insulin, the hormone that rapidly brings it down.

 Fresh fruits give the best slow-release, energy boost, so increase your fruit intake.

 Eat plenty of protein-rich foods, including cheese, eggs, fish and chicken, especially for lunch, if you find that late afternoon is when your blood-sugar and energy levels crash. These foods will enable your body to control its blood-sugar levels more effectively.

 Eat lots of chromium-rich foods, such as cheese, shellfish, baked beans and wholemeal products. Chromium helps your body overcome symptoms of hypoglycaemia (low blood sugar).

 Make sure that you drink plenty of water throughout the day to enable all of the energising vitamins, minerals and slow-release sugars in the food that you eat to be absorbed by your body. Adults should aim to drink 2 to 3 litres of water a day.

 Only drink alcohol when your stomach is full. Because alcohol is absorbed so quickly it causes the blood-sugar level to drop. The presence of food in the stomach slows down the rate of absorption, thereby lessening blood-sugar swings.

 If you are a smoker, try to give up. Nicotine inhibits the body's production of insulin and glucagon, both hormones that maintain a constant blood-sugar level.

Poached fresh figs
serves 6
Magic ingredient figs

Figs contain fructose-fruit sugar, which in the presence of fibre (conveniently also found within the figs) gives our body a slow-release, sustainable energy burst. You may be surprised to find sugar within the juice, but the fig fibre ensures that the sugar is absorbed slowly.

600ml (1 pint) Italian red wine, 225g (8oz) white sugar, 18 fresh, ripe figs

Place the wine and sugar in a non-aluminium saucepan large enough to hold all of the figs in one layer. Warm over a medium heat until the sugar has dissolved. Holding the figs by their stems, drop them gently into the wine-and-sugar mixture. Lower to a gentle heat and simmer for 7 to 10 minutes, until the figs are tender and deep-brown in colour. Using a slotted spoon, remove the figs, being careful that they don't burst, and transfer them to a serving dish. Reduce the syrup for about 6 minutes, or until it has become thick. Pour the syrup over the figs and allow the dish to cool to room temperature.

webTitle: What you won't find at missioncreep.org

fields.headline: What you won't find at missioncreep.org
fields.trailText: Peter Preston: On the press
fields.body:
Once upon a time - my time editing a newspaper - the green file of secrets was locked away in a secure cupboard, to be opened only in quivering emergency. And now? Now all you have to do is call www.dnotice.org.uk/system.htm. The mysteries of the D Notice system are laid bare for anyone to inspect.

Early this summer, the 16-strong committee of media men and Whitehall mandarins which runs what remains of this Cold War exercise in quasi-voluntary restraint produced a re-drafted series of five notices.

They're there on the web. They will be complemented, in the next few days, by an up-grading of the whole site - including minutes of the last committee meeting and a handy reference section called 'Frequently asked questions'.

What do the fettled five say? They are blessedly short and sweetly simple.

Notice one covers military operations, plans and capabilities. It asks editors to consult the secretary of the committee (Rear Admiral Nick Wilkinson RN Retd.) before publishing stuff which could give 'a potential enemy important strategic or operational advantages; which could be exploited by terrorists to devise counter-measures... or endanger lives and put sources at risk'.

Number two: nuclear and non-nuclear weapons. Don't print 'highly classified British technical information on nuclear weapons which could enable others to develop such weapons'. Don't help 'potential enemies or terrorists' with info which means that 'attacks which might otherwise have been frustrated could prove successful'.

Three: ciphers and secure communications. 'Disclosures that could compromise codes and ciphers put at risk the classified information protected by them and, indirectly, people's lives.'

Four: sensitive installations and home addresses. Check before publishing details of nuclear weapons and high-security MoD sites. Check before revealing the home addresses of 'individuals who are likely targets for attacks by terrorists'.

Five: security and intelligence. Go cautiously on MI5, MI6, GCHQ and the Special Forces. Don't print pictures which identify our agents. Don't name their families. 'Publicity about an operation which is in train finishes it.'

The immediately interesting thing about this little list is how lacking in interest it is. The old loose-leaf dossier, with its interminable details of missiles that couldn't be mentioned and operations that didn't happen, has gone (after many months of earnest committee discussion). What remains is really no more than a hymn to common sense. But that doesn't mean there isn't a subtext.

We're already deep into the era of intelligence mission creep - where the adversaries aren't Kremlin apparatchiks with snow on their boots, but drug barons, international crime syndicates and Jack Straw's 'eco-terrorists'.

They, quite specifically, are not covered. They don't count as what the admiral calls 'active threats to national security'. The net, in theory at least, is quite tightly drawn.

Pretty benign? You may reasonably assume so. There is only a 'trickle' of calls seeking advice to Wilkinson's office in the MoD, maybe a couple a day. Most are low-level routine. The press quotient of problems is small - numerically adrift of TV difficulties when SAS men get filmed or book headaches when publishers sign up the latest retired spook for his or her memoirs.

In fact, a conversation with Wilkinson - and some of the senior editors he serves - would seem to make out an unexpected case for the system: not that it's a clammy way of wrapping Whitehall's tentacles round a free press; just the opposite. It was the media side (heavyweights such as Richard Tait of ITN and Phil Harding of the BBC) who pushed the Whitehall side to clear away the Cold War detritus from the notices: and, when they thought about it, the mandarins couldn't see why not.

It is the admiral who self-avowedly roams the back corridors of bureaucracy, telling the civil servants what, in modern times, 'is a secret - and what isn't'. He rather laments the way that too much of the press campaigns only fitfully on secrecy issues. It lets the people who haven't changed think they can get away with it - 'and it means that politicians tend to get involved too late, after the police or whoever have been called in'.

Good works? Yes, in the slightly dotty, chappish mode of British institutional life. (My American friends still roll their eyes over it and choke in incredulity.)

But don't get carried away. The D Notice system didn't prevent the hounding of author Tony Geraghty over his SAS book. It hasn't rubbed balm on the Shayler wound. It has no hand in Jack Straw's plans to let MI5 scan your emails.

Missions keep on creeping insidiously. The secret-service officer tracking drug barons tomorrow may be following Greek terrorists today: the same guy bobbing in and out of the system.

Is Echelon - the American-led intelligence-gathering monster which has got the French so steamed up about business espionage and dirty tricks - covered? Not, presumably, when it's helping compliant Brits win a juicy contract in the Middle East, but absolutely when it's turned on IRA arms shipments. These are deep waters - a sea of confusion which Ministers show no sign of charting.

And then, of course, there's the ungovernable internet itself - a phenomenon for glasnost beyond fixing. That already cuts the D Notice committee out of the action: there's no one to represent the unrepresentable net freelances. Those who live by the web on org.uk will find it precious hard not to die by the web in the end, sponged by relentless dotcoms.

These are deep waters - a sea of confusion which Ministers show no sign of charting.

And then, of course, there's the ungovernable internet itself - a phenomenon for glasnost beyond fixing. That already cuts the D Notice committee out of the action: there's no one to represent the unrepresentable net freelances. Those who live by the web on org.uk will find it precious hard not to die by the web in the end, sponged by relentless dotcoms.
fields.bodyText: Once upon a time - my time editing a newspaper - the green file of secrets was locked away in a secure cupboard, to be opened only in quivering emergency. And now? Now all you have to do is call www.dnotice.org.uk/system.htm. The mysteries of the D Notice system are laid bare for anyone to inspect. Early this summer, the 16-strong committee of media men and Whitehall mandarins which runs what remains of this Cold War exercise in quasi-voluntary restraint produced a re-drafted series of five notices. They're there on the web. They will be complemented, in the next few days, by an up-grading of the whole site - including minutes of the last committee meeting and a handy reference section called 'Frequently asked questions'. What do the fettled five say? They are blessedly short and sweetly simple. Notice one covers military operations, plans and capabilities. It asks editors to consult the secretary of the committee (Rear Admiral Nick Wilkinson RN Retd.) before publishing stuff which could give 'a potential enemy important strategic or operational advantages; which could be exploited by terrorists to devise counter-measures... or endanger lives and put sources at risk'. Number two: nuclear and non-nuclear weapons. Don't print 'highly classified British technical information on nuclear weapons which could enable others to develop such weapons'. Don't help 'potential enemies or terrorists' with info which means that 'attacks which might otherwise have been frustrated could prove successful'. Three: ciphers and secure communications. 'Disclosures that could compromise codes and ciphers put at risk the classified information protected by them and, indirectly, people's lives.' Four: sensitive installations and home addresses. Check before publishing details of nuclear weapons and high-security MoD sites. Check before revealing the home addresses of 'individuals who are likely targets for attacks by terrorists'. Five: security and intelligence. Go cautiously on MI5, MI6, GCHQ and the Special Forces. Don't print pictures which identify our agents. Don't name their families. 'Publicity about an operation which is in train finishes it.' The immediately interesting thing about this little list is how lacking in interest it is. The old loose-leaf dossier, with its interminable details of missiles that couldn't be mentioned and operations that didn't happen, has gone (after many months of earnest committee discussion). What remains is really no more than a hymn to common sense. But that doesn't mean there isn't a subtext. We're already deep into the era of intelligence mission creep - where the adversaries aren't Kremlin apparatchiks with snow on their boots, but drug barons, international crime syndicates and Jack Straw's 'eco-terrorists'. They, quite specifically, are not covered. They don't count as what the admiral calls 'active threats to national security'. The net, in theory at least, is quite tightly drawn. Pretty benign? You may reasonably assume so. There is only a 'trickle' of calls seeking advice to Wilkinson's office in the MoD, maybe a couple a day. Most are low-level routine. The press quotient of problems is small - numerically adrift of TV difficulties when SAS men get filmed or book headaches when publishers sign up the latest retired spook for his or her memoirs. In fact, a conversation with Wilkinson - and some of the senior editors he serves - would seem to make out an unexpected case for the system: not that it's a clammy way of wrapping Whitehall's tentacles round a free press; just the opposite. It was the media side (heavyweights such as Richard Tait of ITN and Phil Harding of the BBC) who pushed the Whitehall side to clear away the Cold War detritus from the notices: and, when they thought about it, the mandarins couldn't see why not. It is the admiral who self-avowedly roams the back corridors of bureaucracy, telling the civil servants what, in modern times, 'is a secret - and what isn't'. He rather laments the way that too much of the press campaigns only fitfully on secrecy issues. It lets the people who haven't changed think they can get away with it - 'and it means that politicians tend to get involved too late, after the police or whoever have been called in'. Good works? Yes, in the slightly dotty, chappish mode of British institutional life. (My American friends still roll their eyes over it and choke in incredulity.) But don't get carried away. The D Notice system didn't prevent the hounding of author Tony Geraghty over his SAS book. It hasn't rubbed balm on the Shayler wound. It has no hand in Jack Straw's plans to let MI5 scan your emails. Missions keep on creeping insidiously. The secret-service officer tracking drug barons tomorrow may be following Greek terrorists today: the same guy bobbing in and out of the system. webTitle: Book of the week: Wild Britain - a Traveller's Guide

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.trailText: Wild Britain - a Traveller's Guide
fields.body:
Wild Britain - a Traveller's Guide, Sheldrake Press, £12.50

This series of books - there's a Wild France, Wild Spain and others - are not for the Ibiza-bound clubber. This is for the hiker and the committed rambler but there's plenty of relish in Douglas Botting's text as he describes his walks through forests and across moors, pinpointing the bird's eye primrose or the kite, a colony of gannets or the pearl-bordered fritillary (a butterfly). Lots of information about where to stay, what to take and which maps are best.

• To order a copy of Wild Britain - A Traveller's Guide by Douglas Botting for £10.50 (rrp £12.50) plus 99p UK p&p freephone 0800 316 6102 or send your order with a UK cheque payable to The Observer CultureShop to 250 Western Avenue, London, W3 6EE.

webTitle: 200,000 defy the Pope in gay march

fields.headline: 200,000 defy the Pope in gay march
fields.trailText: World Pride 2000 ended with a flourish as a crowd claimed to number 200,000 marched to the Colosseum in a victorious coming-out for Italy's gay community, despite the best efforts of the Vatican and the forces of conservatism to rain on the parade.
fields.body:
World Pride 2000 ended with a flourish as a crowd claimed to number 200,000 marched to the Colosseum in a victorious coming-out for Italy's gay community, despite the best efforts of the Vatican and the forces of conservatism to rain on the parade.

Flamboyant costumes were the order of the day, with see-through fishnet outfits a favorite in the daunting (28C) heat.

Among the marchers was a soberly dressed provincial priest marching in solidarity with an event the Vatican had attempted to have cancelled.

'I'm not the Pope, but I'm here!' the Rev Vitaliano della Sala declared.

Other marchers waved cheeky posters poking fun at the Church. 'Sisters are doing it for themselves,' waved one transvestite. 'Nuns on the Run' was worn by a group of men dressed in habits.

David Felix, 54, from San Francisco, wore a placard around his waist: 'God is Gay'. He said: 'I would have loved to have waved this in front of the Pope.'

Later in the afternoon, just past 3pm, the crowd parted for a horse and carriage. As the top was pulled off, the passenger revealed himself dressed as the Pope - with cheap jewellery tacked across his stubby fingers.

A roar of appreciation rose from the crowd as he waved from his seat, and marchers moved forward to kiss his hands, screaming with delight.

fields.headline: Videos
fields.standfirst: Bringing out the Dead | Le Plaisir, Madame De | Limbo | Man with a Movie Camera
fields.trailText: Bringing out the Dead | Le Plaisir, Madame De | Limbo | Man with a Movie Camera
fields.body:
Bringing Out the Dead (1999, 18, Buena Vista, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)
In a virtual reprise of Taxi Driver, Martin Scorsese and screenwriter Paul Schrader return to the mean streets of New York before Mayor Giuliani cleaned them up. Nicolas Cage plays a dedicated Catholic paramedic at the end of his tether as he cares for the derelict denizens of the Hell's Kitchen district, and instead of a slow-mo taxi there's a speeded up ambulance. The movie verges on self-parody, but there are frighteningly funny performances from John Goodman, Ving Rhames and Tom Sizemore as Cage's crazed colleagues.

Le Plaisir / Madame De (1952, PG/1953, U, both Second Sight VHS/Retail, Rental)
The great German-born Max Ophüls, (1902-1957), spent the 1940s in Hollywood before returning to France to direct four magnificent costume movies. The first, La Ronde (1950), is the most famous, the last, the revered Lola Montes (1955), was scarcely shown abroad. The two in between are equally remarkable. Le Plaisir consists of three Guy de Maupassant stories - Le Masque (an old roué attempts to recover his youth), La Maison Tellier (a madame takes her whores for a country outing), La Modèle (a painter marries a crippled mistress) (exquisitely performed by a great cast and beautifully staged (the third tale is shot in Trouville in the manner of Boudin). Madame De, at once astringent and romantic, stars the entrancing Danielle Darrieux (her third Ophüls film) as a wilful French countess whose earrings pass from hand to hand when she falls in love with an Italian diplomat (Vittorio De Sica). The movie is full of graceful tracking shots, the editing is immaculate, the costumes elegant. Next month's Edinburgh Film Festival features an Ophüls retrospective.

Limbo (1999, 15, Col Tri-Star, DVD/Retail)
John Sayles, America's most adventurous independent film-maker, uses Alaska, the country's coldly beautiful last frontier, as a very real place and as a metaphor for the American condition. The film starts out as a semi-documentary exploration of a community in transition, turns briefly into a thriller that evokes Hemingway's To Have and Have Not, and ends up as a wilderness survival yarn. Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio co-stars with Sayles regular David Strathairn.

Man With a Movie Camera (1929, PG, BFI, DVD/Retail)
Directed by the great Soviet theorist and polemicist Dziga Vertov, this classic movie, one of the most ambitious of the silent era, purports to document a day in Moscow. But using every known cinematic device, it wittily and imaginatively investigates the meaning of film, the relationship between image and reality, and the way cinema can transform society. The movie remains as astonishing as the day it first baffled Russian bureaucrats and audiences, and on this DVD it can be seen with a reconstruction of the original score or accompanied by an illuminating commentary by the Russian scholar Yuri Tsivian.

fields.headline: Faith healer
fields.standfirst: Smiths of Smithfield, opposite the meat market in Clerkenwell, is good enough to restore a jaded reviewer's belief in London's restaurants. By Jay Rayner
fields.trailText: Smiths of Smithfield, opposite the meat market in Clerkenwell, is good enough to restore a jaded reviewer's belief in London's restaurants. By Jay Rayner.
fields.body:
A short while ago, a reader got in touch to ask why, given that I was a nice Jewish boy, I did not keep kosher when I reviewed restaurants. The reason, I said, was very simple: THERE IS NO GOD. If solid rationalism did not already tell me this, the pricing policy at Spoon would have convinced me of it. For in a universe with a benevolent deity, such an outrage simply could not be. In any case, a restaurant critic who, through religious belief, had to avoid all shellfish, couldn't mix milk and meat, had to be sure his steak had been drained of blood in the correct manner and that his wine had been blessed by some rabbi working on an hourly rate would be about as much use as a vegetarian in an abattoir. Unless, of course, I reviewed for What Synagogue? magazine.

At least I thought this was why I didn't keep kosher. Now, however, I have discovered the real reason, one that is far more profound than some little character quirk like a complete and unshakeable belief that God does not exist. It is that if I kept kosher, I could not eat at Smiths of Smithfield, a new restaurant in London's Clerkenwell. And that, I have concluded, would be a tragedy of truly cosmic proportions.

Smiths, right opposite Smithfield meat market, is less a restaurant than a complex: on the ground floor is an all-day bar serving huge fried breakfasts in the morning and beer in the evening; on the first floor is a swish champagne bar; on the second floor, a bistro-ish dining room, and up the top - when they finish it - will be a swanky restaurant packed with pressed linen tablecloths and shimmering glassware. It is housed in a funky old warehouse of bare brick walls and stripped floorboards and sharp lights and is the brainchild of the Australian John Torode, late of the Conran empire. In preparation for this launch, he has travelled the length and breadth of the country sourcing rare breeds of livestock so that, once lovingly reared, they may be killed, butchered and served up in his restaurant. The animals may not thank him for it, but I do.

Because the result, at least in the second-floor dining room, comes about as close to my ideal of an urban, wallet-friendly casual restaurant as makes no difference. The food is smart and modern without being self-consciously so, the service is efficient and the prices are entirely reasonable. Which is why I've been there three times since it opened a few weeks ago.

The menu in the dining room is a model of simplicity. Starters are priced at £4.50, mains at £9.50 or £10.50 and puddings at £3.50. On my first visit to review, I began with a chunk of smoked haddock on a mustardy sauce which came with a crispy slice of Gloucester Old Spot bacon. The haddock was a grand piece of fish: the flesh was solid and smoky without being overly salted and the skin was crisp; the bacon added a marvellously meaty kick. My wife Pat said she wanted something soothing, so she chose the potato and lemon soup with fresh rocket, the leaves just dunked into the soft liquid and still fully in possession of their peppery end.

A main course of rabbi-unfriendly crisp belly pork with mash and salsa verde was a grand, solid plateful. Oy vey, but the crackling! It was rendered to a fine crispness and the spiky salsa gave a friendly boost to the mellow flesh hiding beneath. Pat's chicken with black olives stuffed under the crispy skin came on a terrific chickpea mash, thick with fresh parsley and fine olive oil. The chicken itself was not, it must be said, a queen among birds. Though it was perfectly cooked, it tasted of very little, which seems odd given the efforts Torode has made with sourcing. Happily, it was saved by that mash, and doubtless he can go out and find himself a better chicken. By now we were stuffed but, ever the professionals, we forced ourselves to share the Smiths trifle. It was lifted from mundanity by a dark, juicy heap of fresh summer fruits right at the bottom.

Like the menu, the short, carefully chosen wine list is encouragingly priced, with bottles starting at £10 and rising no higher than £23. And all of it - praise the non-existent Lord - is available by the glass. With water, great focaccia bread and a couple of glasses of Merlot, our bill came to under £50. It is very hard to complain.

There are, though, a few gripes. That bill, for example, contained one of those damned 'discretionary' 12.5 per cent service charges. Torode says it is there, rather than wrapped up in the price, because they want to keep the bills down, which doesn't really make sense given that it turns up on the bill anyway. Then again, when the service is this affable, it's hard to begrudge it. On a slightly darker note, a second meal there was marred by some silly cock-ups: a steak that was overdone and a piece of plastic wrapping that turned up on a plate of five-spiced roast duck. Perhaps it is a mark of how much I admire the place that I am prepared to let these things go. It was the day after another glowing review had appeared in the press and, for the first time, they were inundated with punters.

The arrival of Smiths is just about enough to restore my faith in the London restaurant business though, thankfully, not my faith in the Lord. Because if he did exist, I might have to rethink my dietary habits and that, in turn, would mean having to forgo Smiths. That would never do.

 Smiths of Smithfield, 67-77 Charterhouse Street, London EC1 (020 7236 6666). Dinner for two, including wine and service, costs around £55. Contact Jay Rayner at jay.rayner@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Death by design
fields.standfirst: Hand your garden over to the 'experts' and it's not just the hard work you'll miss out on
fields.trailText: Hand your garden over to the 'experts' and it's not just the hard work you'll miss out on.
fields.body:
What are gardening makeovers for? Not for gardening, obviously. A good garden must have humanity, and that can only come through personality, dedication, a sure sense of place and love. The last is a difficult deal - awkward and fumbly on the modern tongue, but unequivocal. There are gardens that demonstrate dedicated work enough and skill of an extraordinary level, but when there's no love involved, the result is sterile and unlovely.

Makeovers are horticultural Muzak. They fill a space entertainingly. That is their function and, as such, they are a resounding success. But you get up from the table hungry. They do not nourish. Good gardens have soul. And I am sure the reason for gardening is to make something beautiful and, at the same time, to nourish the soul. You need both. Opinion might divide on the measure of the former, but not on the latter. A garden with no soul is empty. Gardens must have personality and style; they must never be formulaic or predictable.

I think this is why most professionally 'designed' gardens are no good. It is incredibly difficult to make a good garden for someone else. I have tried and given it up as a hopeless job. (Yeah, yeah, I know, it could be just that my designed gardens were hopeless. But no, they weren't. They were good - though not good enough for me, which is exactly how I feel about nine out of 10 of the professionally designed gardens I see.) It either takes genius - which, happily, does exist - or else a sense of possessing the garden. But chucking money at a piece of outdoors will merely decorate it, and that is somehow depressing - gardens looking like hotel foyers. Perhaps the upshot of this is that public spaces are more amenable to being designed than private ones. The impersonality suits them.

That is what makeovers are: public spaces. They belong to the audience, not to the household. Bland, easy, quick and chirpy. Junk gardening.

Anyone who has a genuine interest in gardening would never get involved in any kind of makeover. Only people who are not interested in gardening, or just lazy, want someone to make over their garden. If you want to change your garden, then get on with it. Nothing beyond the limitations of health, time and money is stopping you. But I know wonderful gardeners with severe disabilities or rotten health, hardly any spare time and no spare money.

The truth is that if you are lazy then you will never garden. Gardening is hard work. Gardening can be difficult, confusing and frustrating. It demands a commitment and a desire to learn and to keep learning. You have to accept that you will get wet and cold, hot and sweaty, sore, tired and depressed. It will cost you money and will take up more time than you have to spare. And this will make you feel, at times, as fully alive and as content as body and mind can be. That's the deal. Everybody who gardens knows that, as deals go, it is a pretty good one.

If you pay someone to come in and 'do' your garden for you in the same way as you might get people in to 'do' your living room or kitchen, it will never be any good. It will not be true - and you can spot a phoney garden the minute you set eyes on it. Anyway, 'doing' a garden is like shovelling the tide, because a garden is never 'done' any more than a river or breeze is 'done'. Gardening is something you really do, privately and without inverted commas.

I write as someone who has done garden makeovers in the past for television and is part of a television culture that manipulates events in order to suit the truth it wants to present within the context of a particular programme. But however you dress them up, other people's gardens are like other people's dreams - so much less interesting than your own. Anyone who has been reading this column regularly over the years will know that just as I prefer to work in my own garden more than anyone else's, so I like writing about my own garden best. I like the way that intimacy with a garden only grows with hundreds and hundreds of hours of acquaintance, of seasonal, even daily change and of the knowledge of your plants from seed to maturity.

This garden Sarah and I have made here is coming to some kind of maturity now, seven years after we began planting. webTitle: More fun at my local barn dance

fields.headline: More fun at my local barn dance
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe rallied in golden evening light to do their bit for post-electoral reconciliation back home. And as for England, well, it's the Test series that matters.
fields.body:
Having been fortunate enough to acquire a prized ticket for the Llangattock-Vibon-Avel Ploughing Society's Annual Country and Western Barn Dance on Friday night, I suspected that I'd had my fill of weekend entertainment even before Saturday dawned.

And so it proved. The Oval was pear-shaped. The action here yesterday was little more than an unwelcome series of comings and goings, whether by black clouds or England batsmen. It was altogether too depressing to think that the wonderful win at Lord's had been a trigger not so much for a revitalisation of our summer sport, but for an all too familiar batting collapse - by a slightly different cast - in the national XI's very next game.

So depressing in fact were events after the dismissal of Marcus Trescothick and Graeme Hick, beacons of comfort in the morning, that it became hard to concentrate. Thoughts wandered to places even worse off than ourselves, to lands darker than the kingdoms of Duckworth-Lewis. This was a case, I hasten to add, not of taking pleasure in the misfortune of others, but of seeking relief in the knowledge, as the blow-fly maggot says, that you're seldom alone in the doo-doo.

We may have had to endure the agonies of Edgbaston, of jilted Henmania and Euro 2000, but at least we've also had Test wins at Lord's and Bloemfontein. Spare a thought for South Africa. They've had the trials of Hansie Cronje, that rugby upset in Bloemfontein compounded by a record defeat under the roof of Melbourne by Australia at the start of the Tri-Nations, and now they've had the 2006 World Cup snatched away from them, courtesy of the one and only Charles Dempsey.

How can it be possible that a 78-year-old Glaswegian Kiwi can determine, by the power of an abstention, where the biggest sporting show on earth goes? Or rather, doesn't go.

Germany needs a second World Cup just 32 years after the first as badly as a Mercedes Benz needs a trim in leather not velour. South Africa needed the World Cup because of a proven correlation between major sporting events there and the greater social good, from short-term crime reduction to long-term nation-building. Witness the Rugby World Cup of 1995.

Charles Dempsey had the power literally to save lives and he bottled it. He wasn't touched by the phone call from Nelson Mandela. He couldn't be compromised by that old bribe. His spirit only broke under the extreme threat posed by the cod fax under his door. Only then did Fifa's Private Godfrey surrender to the Kaiser.

I apologise. But you may have noticed that England didn't bat very well. Either that or the cider at the L-V-A C&W Barn Dance carried a bit of clout.

It was still gloomy at The Oval, but Charles Dempsey had to be put out of mind. This was cricket, after all. Think positive. What was wrong with Zimbabwe doing well? If sport can reduce tension in Southern Africa then may Andrew Flintoff and Robert Croft continue to drill it straight down the throat of long-off.

I was settling into this new, patronising mood when Zimbabwe were suddenly 9 for 2. No matter. They rallied in golden evening light to do their bit for post-electoral reconciliation back home. And as for England, well, it's the Test series that matters. The Oval melted back into shape. The pain of cider faded away along with the echoes of Dolly Parton, cow-shit and an old Kiwi duffer doing his worst for a winter sport.

webTitle: Irritating wait for the return of the real drama

fields.headline: Irritating wait for the return of the real drama
fields.trailText: One-day internationals were incorporated into the cricketing calendar almost 30 years ago. The idea was to introduce vibrant, action-packed cricket to compensate for some of the more ponderous fare served up in Test matches - and to attract the punters. In the wake of the Lord's Test I can't help feeling that we have come full circle.
fields.body:
One-day internationals were incorporated into the cricketing calendar almost 30 years ago. The idea was to introduce vibrant, action-packed cricket to compensate for some of the more ponderous fare served up in Test matches - and to attract the punters. In the wake of the Lord's Test I can't help feeling that we have come full circle.

I'm not alone in being mildly irritated that we have to wait until 3 August for the next Test to begin at Old Trafford. (Alec Stewart voiced the same reservations after England's victory at Lord's.) Instead we must tolerate a triangular series of one-day matches between England, the West Indies and Zimbabwe culminating in a final at Lord's on 22 July.

Let's hope that the sun shines, that the matches are evenly contested and that there is some fine swashbuckling. Even if this is the case they won't be able to match the drama generated by the Lord's game. One-day cricket has become far more predictable than the ebb and flow of the modern Test match.

The Lord's Test was uncommonly exciting but there have plenty of other recent instances when the conclusion of a Test has had us unwittingly gnawing away at our umbrella handles. In the Caribbean there have been the West Indies' victories over Pakistan and Zimbabwe and their epic Lara-inspired defeat of Australia in Barbados 15 months ago. England have contested nail-biters in Melbourne and Leeds (we'll forget about Centurion Park for the moment).

Modern Tests are sometimes one-sided but rarely dull. This is mainly because the bat's predominance over the ball has subsided. In the Sixties both Ken Barrington and Geoff Boycott were dropped for scoring slow centuries; I can't see that happening in this decade. Why are runs so scarce? Is it the pitches, or the development of our stadia into cauldrons that encourage the ball to swing more? Is it the ball? Has the technique of batsmen declined drastically or - and here's an unfashionable view that is unlikely to gain much support from Fred - are bowlers getting better?

Whatever the cause, five days of uninterrupted cricket - especially in England - are a rarity. This dents the coffers of the ECB but when it produces a match like the one we witnessed at Lord's no-one is too bothered. The slow, slow, quick, quick, slow progress of that game was mesmeric. Sales for the remaining three Tests are booming. Channel 4 and their advertisers must be purring and the sporting public is reminded that cricket is not such a dated, tedious game, at which we are pretty useless, after all.

Mind you, it was vital that England should scrape home at Lord's to enliven the rest of the summer. In the aftermath of victory they cannot pay much attention to the old adage 'never change a winning side', though I think Dominic Cork better have another game and so must his pace colleagues, Darren Gough and Andy Caddick. This trio highlighted another turnaround from decades past.

In the Seventies and Eighties the pattern was set: the West Indies whistled the ball past the batsmen's nostrils at regular intervals; England, lacking their firepower, dutifully pursued a line and length. At Lord's we had a mirror image. The key to England's bowling success was that they were hostile; they peppered all the touring batsmen with lifting deliveries and maybe because Caribbean wickets have become slower and slower over the years, the West Indians were flummoxed. Conversely the English batsmen were craving for Ambrose and Walsh to pitch short, which would at least provide an opportunity for scoring. They rarely obliged, though Franklyn Rose did at crucial moments.

Barring injury England's trio of pacemen will surely stay together for the rest of the series. But at Old Trafford, where the ball usually turns nowadays, Robert Croft will presumably be drafted into the final XI instead of Matthew Hoggard. The young Yorkshireman endured an unforgettable Test. He's sure to remember the 45 minutes prowling in the pavilion with his pads on during the Cork/Gough partnership more vividly than anything he did on the field. I'm sure he won't be a one-Test wonder.

However England will have to contemplate major alterations to their batting line up. In fact the best time to change a side is when it is winning so that the newcomers enter a vibrant dressing room rather than a doomed one seeking some startling intervention from outside.

Sadly the reinvention of Mark Ramprakash as a Test match opener has failed. He looks even more tense there than in the middle order and this leads to fatal technical blips rarely sighted when he's playing on the county circuit. Nick Knight, admittedly hampered by injuries at Lord's to his back and in the second innings to his finger, has also been tormented by standard deliveries around his off-stump.

So two places are vacant with three likely candidates to replace them. Nasser Hussain only has to recover his fitness to return as captain - though some runs would be handy as well. The other slot will probably be filled by a left-hander, either old or new. The form of Graham Thorpe and Somerset's 24-year-old opener, Marcus Trescothick, will be monitored closely during the triangular tournament over the next fortnight. Trescothick, an A tourist last winter, has made his mark this year as an aggressive opener and would provide a straightforward replacement for Ramprakash. If they opt for Thorpe then Michael Vaughan would be promoted to open with Mike Atherton. This dilemma will provide a little added spice to the one-day soaps before we settle back to the real drama of the Test series.

The form of Graham Thorpe and Somerset's 24-year-old opener, Marcus Trescothick, will be monitored closely during the triangular tournament over the next fortnight. Trescothick, an A tourist last winter, has made his mark this year as an aggressive opener and would provide a straightforward replacement for Ramprakash. If they opt for Thorpe then Michael Vaughan would be promoted to open with Mike Atherton. This dilemma will provide a little added spice to the one-day soaps before we settle back to the real drama of the Test series.

fields.headline: ITV waits for a signal
fields.standfirst: United merging with Carlton? Granada buying one or both? And what of Sky? Emily Bell  on  money, media - and egos
fields.trailText: United merging with Carlton? Granada buying one or both? And what of Sky? Emily Bell on money, media - and egos.
fields.body:
By this time next week, Michael Green could be the proprietor of the Express, Lord Hollick could have decided to spend more time with his money, Charles Allen could be the sole owner of ITV and On Digital, and Sky TV could land on Earth with the shock takeover of London Weekend Television.

Perm any of the above as Stephen Byers prepares to lift the lid on the most significant shake-up in UK media ownership for a decade. The Trade and Industry Secretary will pronounce, probably this Friday, on the Competition Commission's recommendations for the consolidation of ITV. He will be looking at the proposal that United News and Media and Carlton Communications should be allowed to merge and, separately, a proposal from Granada Media that it should be allowed to bid for either Carlton or United - or both.

Add to this the hints and nods that Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB has made in the past week about possibly attempting to storm the barricades of terrestrial television by petitioning to take part in any ITV consolidation - or, indeed, pick up the severed limbs from the kill.

The alternative, and more conservative, approach would be for Byers to call off any corporate activity at all among the major players until the Communications white paper becomes law - which could take up to two years. Whatever the timetable, there are a number of inevitable outcomes. First, one of Britain's big media companies will certainly disappear, along with its high-profile chairman or chief executive. Two, a national newspaper - the Express - will almost certainly end up changing hands, possibly going to the Barclay brothers, after years of speculation about its future. Third, the Government will be forced to state what its objectives are for the UK's media industry.

'Chris Smith and Stephen Byers do seem to have bought the idea that by allowing consolidation they will create some sort of challenger to the Disneys of this world, though the market doesn't really work like that,' says one industry source. 'But there will be increasing pressure for them to look at the whole media business along straightforward competition lines, and not through the maze of cross-media regulation we have at the moment. That's going to take a lot longer than till next Friday to fix.'

While it is technically possible that as soon as Byers makes his pronouncement the fun will begin, not everyone is convinced it will. 'It is possible that there will be a hostile bid on the table by next weekend, but it seems unlikely. For a start there is no rule that says the DTI has to make an announcement a month after the Competition Commission has submitted its report: it's just convention that it does,' said the source.

Moreover, for any major change in the structure of the television industry - say, for Granada to be allowed to buy everything or for Sky to be allowed for the first time to own any terrestrial franchises - would require a change in primary legislation which, given the sensitivity of the subject matter, is unlikely to be rushed through.

All the smart money is resting on a process that starts with a cautious opening of the lock gates, allowing Carlton and United to merge with certain disposals and allowing Granada to table its own bid for either of these two businesses, but again with heavy commitments to dispose of franchises that tip the company over the existing size restrictions. These largely relate not just to the number of licences any one company can hold, but also to the 25 per cent cap on TV advertising airtime.

But what then? There is no doubt that Granada would rather take over Carlton than United, even though it would give the company a real headache in terms of which London franchise it held on to. There have already been reports of a spurious 'side deal', which would allow Capital Radio to take control of the London Weekend licence while Granada held on to the daily Carlton licence for London. This would almost certainly mean the exit of Michael Green, Carlton's chairman and one of the most colourful figures to emerge from British media over the past 20 years.

Given the stakes, it is highly unlikely that Granada could carry a supine Carlton off to its Stornoway House lair to add to its other trophies - much more likely would be an expensive and contested bid which could also see the terms of the proposed United and Carlton merger rejigged to form a hostile counter-bid to the Granada approach. The combination of media, money and egos will make for a spectacularly bloody battle which will inevitably wrest the control of ITV into one company.

A more disturbing sight for the industry and the Government is BSkyB preparing to push for further liberalisation in the market.

The broadcaster has previously been ruled out as a potential owner of any terrestrial TV licence because of its links with Murdoch's News International - which holds a 37 per cent stake in BSkyB. The 'stop Murdoch' lobby balked at the possibility of the American antipodean taking over any more of Britain's media. There would have to be a mellowing of attitude, not just among the other media owners but also from Labour backbenchers, who have already been stirred by what they see as a threatened 'de-regionalisation' of ITV.

The halfway house that Britain's TV industry is about to enter is also the last-chance saloon for some of its businesses. But with Sky sidelined under current legislation, and Granada listing as a separate media company - it is splitting from its leisure division as of Tuesday - there is a feeling that whatever happens in the short term, there is still a longer end game to play out.

There is always the unwelcome option that Byers will choose to sit on his hands and pass the whole ugly mess over to regulators. But this will produce enormous frustrations among those TV companies who are already in a state of suspended animation. When the Department of Trade and Industry and the Departure of Culture, Media and Sport are faced with an industry that almost unanimously has decided to pull in one direction, it will be almost impossible to rein back.

webTitle: Mandelson speaks up for the euro

fields.headline: Mandelson speaks up for the euro
fields.standfirst:
Minister breaks ranks with move to join pro-European fundraising club
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson is to break his silence on European policy next week with a high-profile appearance at an elite fund-raising event for the Britain in Europe group that will expose rifts on the issue at the heart of the Government.
fields.byline: Kamal Ahmed, political editor, and Martin Bright
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson is to break his silence on European policy next week with a high-profile appearance at an elite fund-raising event for the Britain in Europe group that will expose rifts on the issue at the heart of the Government.

In a move that will infuriate eurosceptics in the Cabinet, Mandelson has agreed to be guest of honour at a party to raise money for the Indigo Club, a group of rich donors to pro-European organisations who have agreed to donate £500 to the cause.

The Northern Ireland Secretary has clashed repeatedly with the Chancellor Gordon Brown over tactics on entry to the single currency. He is expected to pay to join the club in one of the most positive gestures a Minister has made towards Europe.

Britain in Europe officials are jubilant that Mandelson has agreed to attend the event and to talk about the virtues of joining the euro.

When he last spoke on the subject two months ago, he overshadowed a speech by the Prime Minister to the Confederation of British Industry, and again put pressure on the Government's fragile truce on the issue.

At the time a furious Brown told Tony Blair that policy on the euro was an economic decision that would be taken by the Treasury.

The Chancellor is keen to shut down debate on the euro, fearing that the Conservatives can make it into a vote-winning issue at the next election. Political observers point out that Mandelson's appearance at such a high-profile event flies in the face of that wish.

'Of course this is significant,' a source said. 'It will be the first time Peter will be speaking wholly about Europe since the last Labour Party conference.'

Mandelson's move will delight Robin Cook, the Foreign Secretary, and Stephen Byers, the Trade and Industry Secretary, who both believe the Government will have to be more positive about Europe if it is to convince a sceptical public to support British entry.

Yesterday Blair tried to draw a line under his rocky last seven days, saying it was time to concentrate on the substance of politics rather than the froth of spin.

Speaking to the party's National Policy Forum in Exeter, the Prime Minister confirmed that his deputy, John Prescott, would be given a new pre-election mission of improving links between Labour leaders and grass-roots members.

'People complain about petrol prices and I understand that,' Blair said. 'People complain about the choices we made in our first two Budgets and I understand that. But without them we would never have had the strength that we now have got to make our investment year on year.

'Economic strength is our first investment and key public services are the second. Britain has under-invested as a country for too long.'

Prescott joined calls for an end to spinning and carping between Ministers which, he said, was damaging the Government's standing. 'We have to lift our eyes a little from getting all the work done in Government departments and now begin to look at getting our message across,' he said.

'I shall be taking on a special role to make sure not only that we campaign right and get our message across but perhaps redirect and focus our attention on that - and [have] less of the carping between individuals.

'It is damaging. When they get divided in this way, or the press portray them as divided, and they are fed by leaks and snide remarks, it doesn't help parties, whether it was the Tories or indeed Labour parties in the past.'

webTitle: Europe? Invest? It's a bit late, Lord Hanson

fields.headline: Europe? Invest? It's a bit late, Lord Hanson
fields.standfirst: The old predator was wrong about the leaked memo, writes Paul Farrelly
fields.trailText: The old predator was wrong about the leaked memo, writes Paul Farrelly
fields.body:
Who on earth does Lord Hanson think he's kidding? Last week the grandfather of corporate predators savaged Britain's ambassador to Japan for allegedly leaking a memo warning of the dangers to inward investment of not joining the euro.

Yet throughout a 30-year career of looting and pillaging companies (invariably UK and US ones), neither 'Europe' nor 'investment' featured highly on Hanson's self-aggrandising agenda. To the thousands of employees sacked by him and his late partner, Lord White, the reasons are still painfully clear.

Europe, with its stricter employment laws, offered little scope for the unfettered mass firings, closures and sell-offs which went hand-in-hand with Hanson takeovers. And, in the pursuit of short-term profit, capital investment was next for the chop.

Hanson's eponymous conglomerate-to-be floated on the Stock Exchange in 1964 and thrived during the Seventies under the patronage of disgraced City financier Jim Slater. It was in the Eighties however, under Hanson's heroine Margaret Thatcher, that he terrorised British boardrooms by bidding for established names such as Imperial Tobacco, Ever Ready and London Brick.

The scars the Yorkshire haulier's son left on manufacturing industry are still as evident as his blinkering impact on Britain's corporate culture. When Hanson bought Ever Ready in 1982 the firm made 3 million batteries a day and was a leader in its field. When he sold it to US rival Ralston Purina 13 years later, output had slumped, the workforce had halved and its huge London research and development centre had closed. Its UK market share had fallen from 80 per cent to only 35 per cent as the likes of Duracell stole a march with better products.

The story at Imperial Tobacco, bought in 1986, was much the same. While rivals such as Philip Morris and BAT invested in rapid international expansion, Imperial festered with dowdy domestic brands such as Embassy and Lambert & Butler. In 1987 Imperial employed 11,000 people. By 1996, when Hanson flogged the firm off on the stock market, a wave of plant closures had 'downsized the headcount' - as Hanson's accountants might refer to staff - to only 2,750.

Time and time again Hanson bought cheap, sold everything that didn't fit and ran what he kept for cash. Between 1964 and 1986, two thirds of the billions Hanson splashed out on deals was recouped from disposals. In 1991, that fate awaited ICI, but that turned out to be a takeover too far.

For 10 years up to 1996, when he decided to break up the conglomerate, Hanson had greatly underperformed the stock market. True, shareholders who climbed aboard at the start saw a hundredfold increase in their investment. But for many of the 226,000 investors at the end, the 'Hanson experience' was hugely disappointing.

The Treasury, too, suffered. Adept use of offshore tax havens, fancy accounting and financial engineering meant that Hanson's contributions fell well below average UK corporation tax rates.

Not that the Conservative Party moaned. Hanson was consistently the Tories' biggest corporate donor, and one of Thatcher's most strident supporters.

The City, too, had reason to be grateful for the millions of fees clocked up by bankers and brokers on every deal. But arguably the biggest beneficiaries, though, were Hanson, his family and his many protégés.

Even when the group ceased to perform well, Hanson and his colleagues pocketed some of the biggest pay packets in Britain.

Doubtlessly, his dwindling band of supporters will protest at this comment on the old asset stripper's career. After all, he was repeatedly voted Britain's most admired businessman. That, however, was more a sign of the times than any great lasting achievement.

And like his political mentor, the business face of Thatcherism shows little sign of retiring gracefully.

fields.headline: Euro: IT firms 'don't care'
fields.trailText: Leaders of global new economy companies considering whether to invest in Britain put UK membership of the euro near the bottom of their list of concerns, according to an influential survey.
fields.body:
Leaders of global new economy companies considering whether to invest in Britain put UK membership of the euro near the bottom of their list of concerns, according to an influential survey.

Preliminary findings disclosed to The Observer show that the single currency 'barely merits a mention', among chief executives at a wide range of software and computer companies.

The results of the study, by leading consultant Richard Holway, will come as a relief to Government officials and Ministers alike. Both have emphasised the importance of attracting investment to the UK from 'knowledge economy' companies.

The study, which includes the views of bosses at such companies as Microsoft and EDS, is still being finalised. It found that they considered other issues such as capital gains tax rates, National Insurance on company share options, and workers' skills and flexibility to be far more important.

Holway said: 'We surveyed a wide number of chief executives in software design and manufacturing, computing and IT services and asked them to list their priorities. Entry to the euro came so far down the list it barely merits a mention.'

The news comes at the end of a confusing week of claim and counter-claim about the importance of the single currency to inward investors.

Two leaks of high-level documents warning of industrial 'meltdown' if Britain did not join were blamed on pro-euro Ministers wanting to dampen the effect of record inward investment figures from Invest UK, a campaign that encourages inward investment. These suggested British membership did not matter. A presentation by the campaign stressed the importance of investment from new-economy companies, and trumpeted its success in securing it. Invest UK's report says it 'has focused on attracting high-quality knowledge-driven projects'.

One of the leaked memos came from Andrew Fraser of Invest UK, who pointed to possible industrial meltdown if a more positive stance on the euro was not adopted.

Japanese electronics firm Sumitomo Electric Wiring Systems announced last Friday that its plant in Sunderland, Tyne and Wear, is to close. Unions claim up to 400 workers will lose their jobs.

Explosion of e-markets will send company values soaring

The combined value of the all the companies listed on the world's stock markets could grow from the present $20 trillion to $200 trillion in less than a decade because of the way e-business is transforming the global economy, writes Jamie Doward.

A report by accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers says: 'The years 2000-2002 will represent the single most profound period of economic and business change that the world has ever seen, not unlike the Industrial Revolution, but much faster, at e-speed, with most of the change occurring in the next 18 months.'

The development of e-market- places is predicted to explode in the next two years. There are around 750 online market exchanges at the moment, but PwC predicts that there will be 20,000 by the end of next year.

The authors suggest that the global e-markets will bring huge efficiencies, leading to cost reductions of 20 per cent in the next 18 months.

The study forecasts that the changes will raise profits as a proportion of gross domestic product, which in turn will sharply increase the value of companies which embrace new technologies.

fields.headline: Europe's heatwave death toll hits 100
fields.standfirst:
There's no escape from soaring temperatures, reports Helena Smith
Weather watch: special report
fields.trailText: Ten thousand people have been treated in hospital and at least 100 have died as a heatwave which has seen temperatures of up to 48C (118.4F) continues to sweep across the Mediterranean.
fields.body:
Ten thousand people have been treated in hospital and at least 100 have died as a heatwave which has seen temperatures of up to 48C (118.4F) continues to sweep across the Mediterranean.

Temperatures are on average up to six degrees higher than normal, with little respite at night.

Temperatures up to 111F have caused 31 deaths in Athens and 30 in the Yugoslav capital Belgrade during the past six days. More than 3,000 heat victims have been taken to hospital in Athens with breathing problems caused by dangerously high smog levels.

Temperatures of over 40C (103F) are forecast for the next few days as a second wave of hot air heads north from the Sahara.

'It looks like temperatures will go up in the southern Balkans on Sunday by about two degrees,' said Theodoros Kolidas, a forecaster based in Athens.

In Turkey, where at least 11 people have died as a result of the heat, temperatures are hovering around 43C (109 F). Eight died overnight of heart attacks triggered by the heat after temperatures reached 48C (118.4F). Three died of brain haemorrhages.In Romania, five people have died of heart attacks and strokes, bringing weather- related deaths there last week to 14.

The heat was so intense that it triggered emergency systems in a nuclear power plant. It shut down after temperatures inside rose to 70C (158F), setting off sprinklers.

There were also large blazes on the nearby island of Chios, two in the Peloponnese and another near Marathon, about 25 miles east of Athens. The Ionian island of Corfu had fires on two fronts.

Only heavy rain can stop the spread of the fires but there is no prospect of any break in the heat, forecasters say.

In France, two firemen were killed fighting a brush fire in the Bouches-de-Rhone region of southern France.

fields.headline: Demo battle ends truce
fields.trailText: A tenuous truce between young Iranian protesters and rivals among riot police and Islamic vigilantes was shattered last night when the two sides clashed violently in central Tehran.
fields.body:
A tenuous truce between young Iranian protesters and rivals among riot police and Islamic vigilantes was shattered last night when the two sides clashed violently in central Tehran.

Several demonstrators were badly injured as police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd in Revolution Square.

Religious extremists broke through police lines to slash at the pro-reform protesters - mainly students - with broken bottles. The vigilantes handed out clubs and other weapons to supporters.

It was a continuation of demonstrations earlier yesterday, when students protested at Tehran University over the slow place of reform by President Mohammad Khatami.

The violence broke out exactly a year after the worst violence since the aftermath of the Islamic revolution in the Seventies.

Last July police and vigilantes broke into hostels and attacked young people with clubs. The authorities claimed only one person was killed in six days of unrest which followed, but witnesses said the figure was higher. Hundreds of students were injured.

Last night angry demonstrators voiced dissatisfaction with the president, shouting: 'Khatami, Khatami, this is the final notice.' He has been criticised for failing to fight effectively for change.

Students were largely responsible for his landslide election win three years ago. Now, it seems, they will decide the fate of his government.

webTitle: G7 offers peace incentive to Africa

fields.headline: G7 offers peace incentive to Africa
fields.trailText: African countries are to be given substantial financial incentives to resolve regional conflicts, a senior Group of Seven source disclosed last night.
fields.body:
African countries are to be given substantial financial incentives to resolve regional conflicts, a senior Group of Seven source disclosed last night.

The decision comes out of the G7 finance ministers meeting this weekend in Fukuoka, Japan, and will involve urging the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to focus debt relief on countries who are moving out of conflict.

'We believe there will be an increased incentive for these African countries to cease their internecine warfare if there is a large carrot of debt relief,' the source said.

The source said greater progress had been made by the G7 finance ministers meeting than they were admitting, in order for the announcements to be made at the heads of government G7 World Economic Summit in Okinawa later this month.

No formal communiqué was issued, but a summary said world economic prospects were brightening.

The finance ministers agreed to ban 'unproductive aid expenditure' (code for arms and military spending) and to work with the OECD (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development) to ban export credits where the money was destined for arms expenditure.

It is also understood that the British government intends to strengthen its aid effort, bringing together various branches currently working under the Foreign Office, the Ministry of Defence, and the Department for International Development (DfID) under one roof. A Whitehall source said: 'There will be a single line of accountability chaired by the Development Minister Clare Short and a lot more money will emerge from the imminent Comprehensive Spending Review.

The countries where debt cancellation has been stalled are Burundi, the Central African Republic, Congo Brazzaville, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Sudan, Somalia, and Burma. All but one are in Africa.

The summit meeting also examined ways of regulating e-commerce without stifling it; money laundering and further reforms to the International Monetary Fund.

It said the relief of Aids in Africa should be a high priority for the World Bank, which yesterday announced it was preparing a new $500 million programme. Countries would be eligible for 40-year loans.
